Name: Sonja Nguyen
Comments: I both agree and disagree with Crosby. Yeah, humans are terribly destroying the environment and half of us don't even really care for the impoverished. However is that due to the Columbian Exchange? No that's just us as humans. However I can't be so pessimistic. I also can't imagine history any other way. If we didn't have something so significant in history, we'd be a worse world for it. Everything we have now is because of the Columbian Exchange. Not just all the bad things but the good things too.  Better education, more feminism, and ways to support our Earth. So while I do believe in what Crosby says, I still think we need  the Columbian Exchange in our history. Also, as for how this affects how I live, I think it will make me more compassionate and open-minded because your question made me think on both sides of the story while seeing the horrors the Columbian Exchange has caused makes me very humbled. Thank for the questions and keep on giving me food for thought!

Name: Roadly Go
Comments: I feel like this must have been the most terrifying time in all of world history. Imagine people that vaguely match descriptions of your gods showed up on ships the size of your entire village. They steal your stuff and then leave. Then, Your whole village gets sick and starts dropping dead. You try to run away, but then you come to a village your brother told you about approximately 20 miles away. By the time you show up, they are all dead showing the same symptoms as your family. You make your way from town to town because you're an Asymtematic carrier and therefore won't die but everyone else around you does. You're mom. Your Dad. Your Brother. Your Bestfriend. Your Worst Enemy. That random jackass from another village you once got high with. All gone. Eventually, you and the other small handful of survivors find each other, and find another village to be a part of. And then one day, those same gods show back up steal your stuff and then shoot your wife in the face.

Name: Tyler Newman
Comments:
So, about pigs...

Yeah, they definitely breed a lot, but as pointed out (somewhere) in Jared Diamond's popular Guns, Germs, and Steel, pigs are filthy.  They eat anything, and for whatever reason their diseases seem to adapt well to us (i think same reason we can use their insulin, if I understand pig bio - which, i probably don't).   But, among other things, de Soto was not great at keeping all his pigs together (hence the wild hog population throughout much of de Soto's trail).  All these pigs carried these Euro disease (and a bio-stew of other pathogens) throughout the new world.

And horses,
While, yes, horses came with the Spanish in the 16th century, they had similar problems keeping their herd together.  They also used natives as horse-slaves (the ones who weren't otherwise enslaved).  Natives didn't passively submit to their devastation; many would migrate away from Spanish presence and bring the horses with them.  By the time Anglo-French-American settlers began pushing out, several robust cultures began to take shape around the horse.  The Lakota were master horsemen before they ever met a European. 

Unfortunately, the same resistance and inter-relations among Native groups also spread those diseases.  But, it's important to remember that European incursion happened over the course of 400ish years.  In that 400 years, Native cultures shifted, adapted, and resisted.  A lot of discussion seem to box that 400 years into "contact, contagion, conquer," focusing on the European impact.  But, most Native peoples were eventually subjugated by a mature and established U.S.A, not some colonial, European proxy.

Name: Ban
Comments: Isn't the question of whether or not the Columbian exchange was a good thing, an irrelevant one? If an encounter between two vastly different cultures is inevitable, I think there's no point on getting hung up on the merits of the exchange. Debating the merits is like acknowledging that a debate should exist on whether or not they should have explored the America's. But it was an inevitable event, so the subsequent tragedy and exchange of ideas was also inevitable. So who cares about the positive or negative impact. I think a more more interesting thing to discuss is the manner that the European powers colonized the America's and the lasting legacy that those imperial powers left behind. That's the real conversation worth having

Name: Quite the idea
Comments: To (sort of) answer John's question from the end: it's important to remember that we may not be the last form of intelligent life on earth. Humans and AI will someday probably merge, and/or AI's intelligence will radically accelerate to create life forms far more intelligent than we can currently imagine. This is the coming Intelligence Explosion. This would never happen with no Computing Revolution. Which wouldn't have happened without an Industrial Revolution. Which (arguably) wouldn't have happened without a Columbian Exchange to prop up the world economy. If that's rightand if the Intelligence Explosion is more utopian than dystopianthen I submit the Exchange was ultimately overall a good thing.

Name: Stefan Walicord
Comments: Thing is, it was inevitable. Somebody would have found the other anyhow, and as European civilization had a new-found (but deeply rooted) emphasis on discovery, they would have found it at some point. New world civilizations did not have those emphases or abilities, and so the Old would have found the New anyway. While it could have happened less violently, considering human nature, it was... well... to be expected. Not justified, but humans are pretty trash, so it could have gone a lot worse. As for the disease and biodiversity loss, both were inevitable.

Comments: It is not important to discuss weather or not the 'Exchange' was good or bad. The most vital point was its INEVITABILITY.  If Columbus had not arrived in 1492, someone else from Europe, Japan or China would have done so within 50-60 years. They would have brought the same diseases, similar animals, similar plants and exactly the same conquest violence. The so-called 'natives 'and their incapable immune systems were doomed the moment they left Siberia 12,000 years ago.

Name: Ethan Silver
Comments: Yes, I believe that the Columbian Exchange was worthwhile. There are many problems with our society today that stem from the past, but I feel that  it's more worthwhile to think of a solution to a problem than to wish we hadn't caused it in the first place. There were certainly many issues with the Columbian Exchange, but the world is now a much more connected place than it would've otherwise been. I believe that, regardless of the outcome, exploration should not be punished or looked down upon, because it's what makes humans so cool.

Comments: Tbh I think the Columbian exchange was not only necessary, it was inevitable and the earlier it happened the better it really was for humans and our biosphere. Had Columbus not discovered the New World, someone else would have (I know he wasn't actually the first to discover it but he was the  reason the Europeans came over), and they would most likely have come with even worse diseases and possibly have been in a much more brutal mood as they were dying due to lack of food and would've killed a lot more simply to get crops. I think generally when you look at History sometimes the most negative events result in the most positive changes hundreds of years later so its hard to say what would have been the best course for humanity as a whole, especially when the average human consumes something from the New World pretty much every day.

Name: Gloria Li
Comments:
Do you agree with Crosby? Are longer, healthier lives for more humans worth the sacrifice of an impoverished biosphere? And most importantly, how will your conclusions about those questions shape the way that you live your life?

I disagree with Crosby for obviously bias reasons such as I am human and I want to live longer which I will try to justify. I don't think extending human lives means sacrificing the biosphere. I think the question is what are we doing about the environment even though we have extended lives. I think the extension of our age is natural in evolution of the human species. The increase in food, medicine and resources extended our life expectancy. The problem is not that we have better resources suited towards us instead of to the rest of the biosphere. The problem is that people do not care enough to take basic actions at home in order to slow down the depreciation of the biosphere. For example, politicians control the climate of our government that regulates things such as CO2 emissions. Perhaps if people committed to the Paris Climate Change agreement instead of letting their greed take over then maybe it will still slow down the depreciation of the biosphere. No matter what I think the biosphere will constantly be changing and species will evolve or die out. It's a matter of how quickly. 

In addition, regular people at home in developed countries consuming more than most people in developing countries should learn to use less and waste less. I disagree with Crosby because that would mean if the Columbian Exchange didn't happen then a lot of innovation and technology that can solve our current problems wouldn't exist. In conclusion, I think we are fighting against our own greed as a society instead of the battle between humans and other species.

Name: Katie
Comments: While whether the benefits outweigh the costs is an interesting question, it's rather moot, isn't it? Not moot because it already happened because I enjoy what-ifs and hypothetical alternate histories. But total globalization didn't just happen, it was always inevitable. That's like saying what if I never turned 23? Unless I died, existence supposes that I was always going to age up a year. There is no version of world history that doesn't include a globalized world with all of the disfigurements that come with its transformation. The only question answered by debating if the costs outweigh the benefits is whether we should cry about it or not.

Name: Ivan Engel
Comments:
Nietzsche didn't have syphilis:
"A study of medical records has found that, far from suffering a sexually-transmitted disease which drove him mad, Nietzsche almost certainly died of brain cancer.
The doctor who has carried out the study claims that the universally-accepted story of Nietzsche having caught syphilis from prostitutes was actually concocted after the Second World War by Wilhelm Lange-Eichbaum, an academic who was one of Nietzsche's most vociferous critics. It was then adopted as fact by intellectuals who were keen to demolish the reputation of Nietzsche, whose idea of a "Superman" was used to underpin Nazism." The Telegraph

You can already see it happening, and it's not necessarily a bad thing. Although Mr. Smith might've been right when he said humanity is a virus. These were phases humans had to go through. We've learned a lot since then, haven't we? That's why we can retrospectively look back and have this discussion today.

But I also think we have very short memories, and in spite of all efforts to remember and learn from history, we're bound to forget. It's in the genes. I cannot see whether maturity as a species is at all possible. How easy it is to brainwash a whole generation and build a different age from that. The brainwashing is going on, even now... 

How should society change in order to cultivate informed people who will be responsible for themselves, each other, and the planet? Do you think humanity has an ultimate form? And if it does, will we live long enough to reach it before destroying ourselves?

Or don't you think we like our wars and our struggles, and if we didn't have them, then what value is there to even living?

Everyone seems to have their own idea of an ideal world, whether that world is the bubble they live in, or the whole planet. Everyone's striving for something. There's no such thing as good or bad, so how do you know who's right, what's better, what should be done? And if we even work for that cause, who's to say it's doing more good than harm?

Gahhh I hate the questions your questions make me remember! I have enough trouble figuring out what to do with myself, let alone the rest of the world. I don't actually really wanna deal with this. Sometimes the weight of it all crushes me and I feel so helpless. I mean, does it even really matter what I do with myself in the grand scheme of things? Everyone should just hold hands and walk to oblivion together. That's simpler and cleaner.

Name: Andrea Payne
Comments: BAHHHHH grapes are native to the Americas too.  In fact the modern vineyard has both European and American vines growing in them.  the bottom half of the grape vine is American but the top (the part that actually produces the grapes) is European for the most part.  Even in Europe this holds true.  You can thank an American pest that nearly destroyed the European vineyard industry for that.  The American species is resistant to this pest whereas the European species is highly susceptible.   By grafting  the American root to the European fruit producing section you get a resistant plant!  The more you know!

Name: Supadubya
Comments: Crosby's a moron.  "Not a richer, but a more impoverished genetic pool".  Seriously, WHERE DOES HE GET THIS STUFF?  He clearly doesn't understand biology or genetics, at all.  The knitting together of previously isolated human populations allowed for gene flow between them (through migration, intermarriage, and reproduction), essentially creating one larger genetic pool.  And, speaking as a trained biologist, it is an unequivocal and well-known fact by any expert in the field that having a larger population leads to higher genetic variability due to reduced loss of traits due to genetic drift.  That is, one large, interconnected population can support far more genetic variability (both for good, as with beneficial traits, and for ill, as with recessive genetic diseases) than a set of smaller, isolated populations with the same total membership (and the Columbian Exchange also led to long-term increases in population size- after a bottleneck that lasted too few generations to significantly reduce genetic variability...)  In short, it is a KNOWN FACT that the Columbian Exchange enriched the genetic pool, and anybody who says otherwise in the matter of Crosby is speaking out of ignorance of a field (genetics) that they have no real understanding of...

They were well-built, with good bodies and handsome features.... They do not bear arms, and do not know them, for I showed them a sword, they took it by the edge and cut themselves out of ignorance. They have no iron. Their spears are made of cane... . They would make fine servants.... With fifty men we could subjugate them all and make them do whatever we want." 
Native Americans offered nothing but love to Columbus and he offered his blade...

Name: Austin Myers
Comments:
A bit of a tedious correction, but Nietzsche probably didn't die of syphilis, and it's my understanding that he actually died of a cancerous tumor in his brain. The syphilis story was spread as part of an anti-Nazi smear campaign. This is made even more tedious by the fact that most scholarly interpretations of Nietzsche read his philosophy and himself personally as decidedly anti-Nazi himself, albeit at least a little bit racist. Apparently, in his time, he was understood by many as such, largely due to misunderstanding and perhaps just purposeful removal from context to manipulate his words. 

I recently took a class on Nietzsche in which our professor broke down this mind-boggling and unfortunately catchy lie. In fewer words, some anti-Nazis invented this syphilis story to smear someone who was actually not pro-Nazi at all.

Team of (no longer pseudo?) historians, does this check out?

Anyway, thanks little Johnny Bookwriter for this wonderful series. Maybe someday I'll be able to have actual intelligent discourse with a real life person-who-knows-friggin-anything-about-history instead of just becoming embarrassed and silent.

Name: Jessica Manuel
Comments: I'm in love with the Colonial Era and the age of discovering new lands however the heavy tragedy of it all is that it was the beginning of a new age of corruption. Many of the Spanish Conquistadors mainly wanted to conquer lands due their quest for gold - as well as wanting to change the pagan beliefs they encountered in turn for Catholicism. Thus it is hard to determine whether it was a great thing such expeditions were made as it started of civil wars and slavery. However without it happening, there would have been no America today - and if we were to still live in the Old World ideology then we would be living our lives in a thoughtless bubble.

I agree with Crosby. Europeans were the biggest beneficiaries of the Columbian exchange and used it as a platform to spread colonial devastation to every corner of the globe. The poverty and/or instability of African nations, tensions in the Middle East by overthrowing governments, installing tyrants, and redrawing borders, the desecration of history (e.g shooting at the sphinx), and the enslavement, slaughter, and marginalization of peoples from the Americans to the Aboriginals. I'm not even going to begin to talk about the ecological impacts unless you want an entire dissertation. 

The Columbian exchanges' negative impacts BY FAR outweigh the good. What good is it if the world population doubles if certain segments of the world population have to be decimated and/or enslaved to make it possible?

Name: Colin W
Comments:
In response the quote from Alfred Crosby Jr. at 0:22-0:28, the best selling authors of Freakonomics remind us that thinking big is not always the best method. Here's an exert to justify their reasoning:
Small questions are by their nature less often asked and investigated, and maybe not at all. They are virgin territory for true learning.
2.Since big problems are usually a dense mass of intertwined small problems, you can make more progress by tackling a small piece of the big problem than by flailing away at grand solutions.
3.Any kind of change is hard, but the chances of triggering change on a small problem are much greater than on a big one.
4.Thinking big is, by definition, an exercise in imprecision or even speculation. When you think small, the stakes may be diminished but at least you can be relatively sure you know what youre talking about.

So this all sounds great in theory, but does it really work?
Wed like to think our own track record says yes. While we havent done much about the worldwide scourge of traffic deaths, we did highlight one category of high-risk be

Excerpt From: Steven D. Levitt. Think Like a Freak: The Authors of Freakonomics Offer to Retrain Your Brain. iBooks.

Name: ismelljello
Comments:
Could you imagine what the New World would look like today if old world disease had not been a factor during the Colombian exchange? You'd have preserved armies at full strength spanning across the American continents, ready to defend their respective empires.

The sheer numbers, preserved organization and acquirement of Old World ideas and technology (and potential improvement) would have been a sort of steroid for the indigenous national consciousness,

These nuances would have most likely jettisoned Native peoples to the forefront of the world stage. Their endless resources and newly acquired social/technological advancements would have made their endless and inevitably unified numbers into a world power house.

Imagine the brown man defending his coastal borders all along the Atlantic with the very muskets his people traded for or learned to make.The numbers of these newly evolved peoples would be far too much any one European country to even think of confronting.

Should the benefits of the Old World have reached a people who's population hadn't been decimated, you'd be right to imagine no truer rival for the Europeans than the Natives.

Even after the Native holocaust, it still took American settlers until 1890 to get these road warrior like stragglers who's ancestors evaded disease to admit defeat. Imagine their ancestors at full strength. Imagine how history would have played out.

Name: Rahsaan Footman
Comments:
The question this Crash Course lays is essentially a hollow one. First, Mr. Cosby goes back and forth between summation (all the damage total) and the momentary (what damage is done at a given point of time ) Take an argument about Old World diseases killing so many natives. A counter argument is that 100% of those people and Europeans that visited their lands are dead. Another way to see this is that at the time extinctions of certain plants and animals is a bad thing. But at the time finding and growing enough to eat at the time is a good thing. Slaughtering buffalo may seem bad, but cutting down the competition for grazing cattle to feed a city, nation, world is seen as a good.

The reason I call it a hollow question is because there is no way to hold accountability. The most we can do is decide whether to identify with those ancestors who do things we'd disagree with. I can't say I make a choice based on how someone years, decades or centuries in the future will judge it. I certainly can't expect others to.

Name: GeneralCox
Comments:
enjoying the videos, nice to get a view of history from the America's (which is angled differently to Europe's). It must be said that it comes across that there is a very thinly vailed hostilityto the European view of history, which is countered by the almost gleeful mention of the 'new world'. I am trying to find out more about what was happening outside of my sphere of the world without prejudice and hope that when writing these in the future, there is more of an attempt in the broad scope of the videos to capture an unbiased view of these points.

On a more video focussed note, in my view the Colombian exchange is one of the worst things to happen to the planet, up there with pretty big meteor strikes. Decreasing biodiversity and the eventual explosion of the Human population, with all the subsequent resource mining and pollution which we brought with us, we are still living in the legacy of this event hundreds of years from its happening and will be for the foreseeabel future.

Name: Skerdy
Comments: I think of it as just inevitable. Colombus was not the first European to reach the Americas... actually, all the Natives are descendants or Eurasian nomads from Siberia and the first thing they did is to hunt into extinction mamoths and the animals that ate them like the saber-tooth tiger. We think of this "Columbian Exchange" as relevant because it impacts our lives but in truth this is just an episode as many others in evolution history. It just happened faster than others due to humans, but that doesn't make it any different qualitatively.

Name: Emily Baker
Comments: There's no direct evidence that Nietzsche had syphilis, much less that it caused his mental decline. More recent scholarship suggests that he suffered a degenerative neural genetic disorder such as frontotemporal dementia. See Google Scholar results for "Nietzsche frontotemporal dementia" for sample cites.

Name: Roberto Alexander
Comments: Randomly came across this channel this past weekend, and I have been watching the videos nonstop. LOVE THEM. Honestly, I have stuck with World History (just for now, trust me), because, well, I have always loved history. And it is fun to relearn, remember, and learn some new things (like, I never realized how illogical it is to call the Renaissance Period an actual period, and how Eurocentric!). One of the things I liked about the videos so far was that it refused to ignore China, Africa, Islam, the East Indies, etc. I am now 28, and most of my world history lessons revolved around Europe. Still, I am a bit disappointed that the Native Americans (both North and South) have not been mentioned until now. Browsing through the next few videos, it does not seem like the Incans, Mayans, etc will get the same treatment that the Egyptians, Greeks and Mongols did, even though their Empires, culture, and intellect still impact the world today. Will they at some point? It would be great to go into more detail about the great American civilizations and native peoples, and I would love to see the African peoples also get more "screen" time. Overall though, AhMayZing :)

Name: CrimsonVocals
Comments: Are longer, healthier lives for more humans worth the sacrifice of an impoverished biosphere? It is our responsibility as the current custodians of our world to make that sacrifice worth the damage. I certainly want my longer life to be worth it, because the sacrifice has already been made. Our history is already finished and all that is left is to do what we can with what we have now. As Theodore Roosevelt said, "In any moment of decision, the best thing you can do is the right thing, the next best thing is the wrong thing, and the worst thing you can do is nothing." or more simply, "Do what you can, with what you have, where you are."

Name: Amanda Rushing
Comments: In regards to the poorer gene pool situation, I would like to point out that among the Mayan empire, there was so much inbreeding among the upper classes that the merchants were sometimes allowed to take upper class spouses just to add new blood to the mix. Among the P'urepechas, there was so much inbreeding that harelips were really common and caused a great number of deaths, so yes a bunch of people died but when the Spanish came over they took native wives, and their children were born with access to both the cultures of their mothers and the disease resistance of their fathers. Nothing is as black and white as history likes to paint it, and the ancient cultures of the past, while fascinating, should be understood entirely, not just idealized.

Name: Ashtarte
Comments: It always bothers me when history books or whoever else makes the claim that more species have died in the last 400 years than normal process. This is blatantly wrong, nor could it be proven if it were. Over 90% of all extinct species were extinct before mankind even existed. Climate change is something you can point to mankind and say is our fault, extinction is not. Mankind has actually had little hand in most extinctions in recent years, it's just evolution taking course.

Name: Shannon Fickling
Comments: I'm a bit surprised that you talked about animals and disease but not how the two are related. The main reason (according to my college history teacher, correct me if I'm wrong) that Native Americans were not immune to smallpox and other European disease because they did not have domesticated animals/livestock, or at least not the kind they had in Europe. This was one reason they switched to African slaves. Africans did have livestock, and therefore had been exposed to smallpox before so most of the population was resistant to it. Anyways, I just thought I would share this because I found it very interesting.

Name: Mark Davis Jr.
Comments: Grapes are a worldwide fruit, what the Europeans brought over is Vitis vinifera. In the 1800's English botanists brought phylloxera to Europe to study it, leading to a breakout and near total destruction of V. vinifera vineyards. Following the infestation they started grafting the European V. vinifera onto American rootstocks. The only two places in the world now not infested with phylloxera are Washington State and Chile.

Damn, it seems that just as "all roads lead to Rome", the unavoidable question that the study of history inevitably leads to is "Why do we exist?"

And very ironically, yet deliciously so, the the answer to this question, most reasonably seems best found in the study of prehistory --- that time of stark, day-to-day, hand-to-mouth survival wherein the our ancestral forebears would have answered, had they possesses the language skill to do so, that, "Duh, we exist to exist; what else, Einstein?"

Name: oceandrainer
Comments: I think making a moral judgement on the Columbian Exchange is moot. It happened--it is neither right nor wrong. Neatly dividing whole  groups of people as "Europeans" or "Native Americans" is useful for categorization when discussing history, but it is hardly enlightening beyond that. Humans interact, live and die. That is one of the few true "facts" of history. The rest is a matter of opinion. With your opinion, you will almost certainly find facts to fit your preconceived notion of history.

Name: Wesley King
Comments: There are two variations of it, one that's poisonous and one that isn't. The sweet variety has very little cyanide (yes, that's right, cyanide) and that's probably the kind you're thinking of. The bitter variety has lots in it, and cassava is known to contain more cyanide if it is grown in drought conditions. Some people prefer the bitter version. In fact, there is a very tasty broth you can make by boiling away the cyanide from the liquid drained from the starch of cassava.

Name: Archronis
Comments: No sir, they are suffering in the wake of colonialism, slavery, Manifest Destiny, segregation, reservationism and a dozen other deliberate human atrocities. Do not confuse those with the Columbian Exchange. Nobody alive is suffering for the sake of the intercontinental exchange of plants, animals and microbes that occurred 500 years ago.

Name: Solarn40
Comments: Also, Native Americans and black Americans. They are still suffering from the effects of the Exchange.

Name: Solarn40
Comments: Oh hey, I didn't even notice someone commented on the same thing I did, except better and earlier.

Name: Solarn40
Comments: Here's the thing about Crosby's words in the end. Do YOU want to go back to a world where you live in your own little community and never see anything else in your entire life unless you go into commerce? And where trade is so difficult and expensive that communities have to sustain themselves, usually just on the limit of poverty? And to be honest, diversity of the genepool means nothing if those oh so diverse parts of it are locked away from each other.

Name: Archronis
Comments: Also, Crosby's understanding of genetics is wanting. We do not have "a more impoverished genetic pool." Yes, among humans, TOTAL genetic diversity did decrease somewhat, but each extant population has a MORE diverse gene pool as a result and genetic diversity is continually increasing on its own. Crosby makes an erroneous distinction between the extinctions that resulted from the Exchange and those of evolution, when the Exchange was merely an event affecting the conditions of natural selection.

Name: Archronis
Comments:
Crosby: "We, all of life on the planet, are the less for Columbus, and the impoverishment will increase."

This is not quite true. Yes, the people alive during and for some time after the Columbian Exchange were decimated, impoverished, generally and profoundly harmed by it. But we today are not suffering for it, we are reaping the benefits because generations before suffered. There is still suffering in the world, but not a direct result of the Exchange (unless you count food-bearing animals).

Name: Erazoic
Comments: In response to the question, I don't think the focus should be turned to whether or not the Columbian Exchange was a good thing, but rather accept its existence and impact and, based on what we know today, lessen the negative impacts (such as those on the environment and extinction) as best we can, and further the positive impacts (which I believe to be the more human effect of globalization and whole-world communication).

Name: Gideon
Comments: Yeah, while on holiday in the U.S., we visited a replica village thing in cape cod. There was a replica colonial village and a replica native american Wampanoag village. In the native houses, the beds were raised off the floor by about three feet, and were generally designed to be clean and comfortable. The colonial bed was very uncomfortable, very low down and very unclean.

Name: James Donald Feenstra
Comments: I'm sure others might have better answers, but one reason might the lack of domesticated animals in the Americas. Domesticated animals are big disease vectors, and so people who lived in societies with domesticated animals would be more accustomed to the disease environment they created, and build up immunities. People without domesticated animals would lack such immunities.

Yes, we are used to wild berries as well, that's why I was so surprised, it seems natural and like it's been here since forever. There aren't any farms I know of and if you buy blueberries over here, they are the wild, forest ones. Strawberries were always cultivated and farmed.
Tho given that "traditional" Italian combo is tomatoes and basil, one from America, the other from India, I guess I shouldn't really be.

Name: InedibleHulk Smith
Comments: Maybe they were brought to your region for growing, but accidentally spread to the forest, as well. Maybe they were purposely left in the forest so people could do that. Do you have no berry farms at all in the Czech Republic?

Name: Bishop38f8
Comments:
Yes i know, but berries are edible, they are not accidents like some invasive plants that were brought by other means. I would have expected humans to actually use them, and they probably had to, in some way, at some point, otherwise the berries wouldn't have spread at all. Most edible plants from America are used in agriculture since, like those potatoes, tomatoes, etc.

Why bring delicious berries and then completly leave them be?

Name: InedibleHulk Smith
Comments: An invasive plant doesn't need to be cultivated. Sometimes you just need to accidentally scatter some seeds. If animals end up preferring blueberries to whatever they used to eat, more seeds will spread in their fur and turds. Before long, the old plant is completely forced out.

Name: ncebel29
Comments: It's true that Native Americans hunted buffalo before horses were brought over, but never before in such great numbers. Buffalo were never the focus of life like they became after horses were introduced, because they were much harder to hunt on foot.  Horses allowed them to hunt buffalo more efficiently and in greater numbers than they had before, which made the practice more profitable not just as a method of subsistence, but also economically, since the hide was a highly valued trade good.

Name: blaegme
Comments:
In spite of what mister crash course said: Indians didn't abandon anything to hunt buffalo on horseback and most Indians didn't as most buffalo lived in the great plains, while Indians lived all over North America. 

The plains Indians had hunted buffalo long before any horses where brought to North America. They in fact followed them, living a nomadic lifestyle.

Name: azadkamall
Comments:
The confusion comes about because often ppl use the word "America" to describe one country (USA). But "The Americas" refers to the whole of North & South America (all the way from Argentina to Canada).

With that in mind, if I then tell you my friend is "American", do I mean that my friend is from USA, or do I mean that my friend is from somewhere in North or South America???

There's no right answer to that as it could mean either. Hence the confusion (and it can sometimes lead to arguments).

Name: Harrison Wilterdink
Comments: Your marble slab example illustrates brilliantly how the phrases "decreasing complexity" and "increasing entropy" are not the same thing. Your example shows how we can increase entropy while simultaneously increasing complexity. Hence, the second law of thermodynamics does *not* tell us that complexity on Earth must perpetually and inevitably decrease.

Name: PseudonymousCypher
Comments: Well yes and no. While it is quite true nature tends towards specialization, the whole topic boils down to the simple scientific fact that, within a closed system, overall entropy always increases. For example say you carved a statue out of a slab of marble. While you may have created something that we would consider more complex, ultimately if you measured all of the energy and change you made to the system, it turns out you still increased the overall entropy.

Look at a coral reef, the ancient ecologies of different continents, or even simply the small ways in which introduced European species have changed in response to new environments. Name: Harrison Wilterdink
Comments: To clarify: According to the common definitions used in thermodynamics, a closed system can have energy move in and out, but not mass (e.g., atoms).  As a reasonable approximation, we can think of Earth as a closed system.  However, I think PseudonymousCypher was thinking of an isolated system, in which both mass and energy cannot move in and out.  Earth is definitely *not* an isolated system.

Name: Harrison Wilterdink
Comments: I like your thinking, but the science here is false on at least one account. The main one is: Decreasing in complexity is *not* the same as increasing in entropy (likewise if you substitute "order" for "complexity").  For most practical purposes, a system that is increasing in entropy either has (a) energy (e.g., heat) spreading out in space, and/or (b) mass (e.g., atoms) spreading out in space.  "Complexity" is much broader than "entropy," and it's risky to use them interchangeably in science.

Name: Joseph Quinlisk
Comments:
Were bison ever domesticated?  If so, why are there cattle everywhere?  And if they weren't, why not?  My friend pointed this out to me a few weeks ago, and it's been bugging me ever since.

In non-answer to the big question, I think that the Columbian Exchange was in some sense inevitable.  Granted, it would probably have gone marginally better if, say, Zheng He had done it, but I don't think that would have made much of a difference in the initial disease-induced devastation.

Comments:
Historically, we cannot pinpoint an accurate time period as to when Mayans started dying out.
However, historians do believe that Mayans started killing themselves off (through ritual sacrifice and tribal conflict) at around the 900s-1200s, even before Columbus came to the Americas. And keep in mind, this video, The Columbian Exchange, is named *for* Columbus.

Best wishes, A Guy With No Life.

Comments: No one deabates wether he was a politicasl genius or not. How come nations that belonged to this system did not help the Spaniards? Tlascaltecs were already enemies with the Aztecs.

Name: MrMymoset

Name: NickGreyden
Comments: Since man started moving, he was in most ways considered a natural force. Therefore, the extinction of plant and animal life that occur, DUE SOLELY TO INTERACTION, is nothing more than part of an evolutionary environment. As the adage goes, adapt or die. As a higher form of life (I use that term with some trepidation), we also are responsible for our actions and can even assist adaptations with technology. The main roadblock along that road is ignorance and limited technology.

Name: Casey Patterson
Comments: The way I figure it, the Columbian exchange was more or less inevitable.  At some point, someone would realize that there is an entire other hemisphere, and interactions were bound to ensue.  Unless they had a very fortunate an unlikely insight into the nature of disease by the point of said interaction, the negative effects of the exchange would be largely the same.  Like any other famine, epidemic, or natural disaster, we should recognize the tragedy of it but not try to attribute blame.

Name: rachaella22
Comments: I'm taking Native Studies in university and there's one aspect of this video that I thought warranted commenting on. You, like most history textbooks, refer to the indigenous peoples of the Americas as being led by male figures. However, most of the native communities were actually matriarchal. The Europeans refused to do any kind of business with women, though, forcing a dramatic shift in the social structures of the natives. I just thought it was interesting to point out. Loving the videos!

Diversity is good because because there are some really good genes and some really bad genes and lots in between, when things like natural disasters or man made one like foreign species are introduced, the strong live and the weak die.  This creates a temporary drop in diversity until the strong remaining animals and genes begin to diversify, creating a stronger and more diverse population.
competition is good you just have to look long term, ie. "no pain no gain".

Name: winterking07
Comments:
1)  It's not that difficult.  History can come from quite a few sources besides written books.  Beyond the writing of the Maya (and Aztecs, and maybe Inka), we have archaeology and anthropology, which can tell us as much about early civilization in the Americas as they can about Mohenjo-Daro.

2) False.  One example not covered by the Columbian Exchange is the effects of Indian activities in creating the American environments that later Europeans encountered.

Name: winterking07
Comments:
Well, that's a fair point.  It's what happens when a culture is almost annihilated.

Still, '1491' makes some arguments to the contrary, most interestingly that the study of precolumbian history teaches us that the first Americans didn't 'live lightly on the land'; they changed/controlled their environment in many ways--and so our present-day understanding of environmentalism and wilderness is based partly on false ideals of some pristine, primordial nature.

Name: winterking07
Comments:
It is getting increasingly out of place, if it is coming up in the future.  The Columbian Exchange destroyed those civilizations, and next week is the slave trade, which reached its peak well after that destruction.  

I hope I'm wrong, but even if I am, we've missed the reasonable place for the topic.  (And part of my point is that even if they weren't involved in Eurasian trade, the history of the Americas before Columbus is worth studying.)

Name: winterking07
Comments:
That's disappointing, if true.  I'd think one of the benefits of this format would be the freedom to cover neglected areas of history.  

(And I don't think he's strictly following any AP World History curriculum--I don't imagine it goes into much depth about Zhang He, or ties everything back to the Mongols, for example.  Or has an entire lesson about the Turks and Venetians.)

Comments: I say that Columbian Exchange enriches Malaysian culture, well, not directly, but still. Nasi Lemak, a national food of the Malays, are not possible without chilli and peanuts, two plants from the New World. Cassava saves Malaysian lives during the Japanese occupation, when the crop rice, the only staple Malaysians will eat, are confiscated. The Bugis Tribe didn't eat rice except on Mondays and Thursdays, subsisting on cassava flour instead. So, thanks Columbus.

Name: Silver7Bullet
Comments: Yup; this is true - we talked about it in my Vegetable Crops class. Another major old root crop was the Rutabaga. In addition to being easier to grow, potatoes produce more food per acre than the other root crops, and they have a more mild flavor.   What's really interesting is that the wild ancestor of the potato was toxic (the leaves and fruit of the potato are still toxic - so don't eat them). Parsnip leaves are also toxic; but they cause a rash when you touch them with bare hands.

Potatoes were domesticated in the Andes mountains.  Once they were imported to Europe, they took off and did indeed supply many regions with food, but they had to cross the oceans first.

Name: winterking07
Comments:
The US, and about a decade. This course HAS covered a lot, it's true, but it's still just covering the classic Eurasian subjects, albeit in more depth (which is good!).  

We've only touched lightly on African history, and John's skipped the entire Western Hemisphere's pre-colonial history, from the rise of the earliest civilizations on the Andean coast and in Mesoamerica, to the heights of the Inka and Maya, to the mound builders. 

There's no good reason reason to skip so much.

Name: Scott Bayley
Comments: I do not like the question, John.  It presupposes that we have arrived at our destination, and it is time to dust ourselves off and assess how well we did. Let us look forward.  It is important to study history, but once we identify what was good about the past and what was bad, the next step is to increase the awesome and decrease the suck. It is pointless to ask if the Columbian exchange was GOOD or BAD, as if it was a novel that we just finished reading.

Name: Scott Bayley
Comments: It was not brutal violence that primarily killed the Aboriginal people.  Of course brutality was very real, that I do not deny, I object only to your assertion that violence was the PRIMARY cause. For example, the Huron people experienced wave after wave of plague before any of them ever met a European, as the plague spread from French to Algonquin to Huron. Prior to 19th century Europeans had no germ theory.  They could not possibly have intentionally spread disease.

Name: LtStJebus
Comments:
There were horses in North America over 10,000 years ago, but they died out. They weren't the same as the ones brought over by the Europeans, but were a closely related species (also genus Equus I think).

So humans used to live with horses in the Americas long ago, but they had been without them for at least 10,000 years before being reintroduced. 

Though whether or not those horses were essential to their culture was probably a guess on behalf of the Smithsonian Institute.

Comments:
My take: Environmentalism for its own sake is kind of a funny thing.  We are a part of the ecosystem, for better or worse.  We are undoubtedly the most powerful living creatures on the planet, and could decimate any other living thing, had we the desire.  

Nature doesn't care.  As far as the earth is concerned, it would be just as happy as a barren rock as it would an ecosystem.  So why do we care?  Why DO we care?

Environmentalism isn't for the environment's sake. It's for OURS.

Name: Patrick Sims
Comments:
The thing about Australia that's so fascinating is that it's the land that the rest of the planet was searching for for a very long time, and not found in any meaningful sense; apart of course for the native ancient Aborigines, who basically had the run of a whole continent, undisturbed for tens of thousands of years.

The relatively modern Pacific islander peoples managed to get all the way to New Zealand and Hawaii without colonizing it!

Name: David Palmer

but then you also get into the other paradox, which is used by some sci-fi shows, where what you do in the past you have already done (as past cannot be re-written) therefore you change nothing.

Another type exists, where the observer is unaffected. and can return to their time with the memory of life prior to the change.

A lot of people believe time travel to the past is impossible, because it is too confusing

Name: Travis Rosenlieb
Comments:
It is interesting to juxtapose the loss of genetic diversity with the capacity for new ideological diversity. As the world gets smaller, information flows more freely and in so doing undergoes a process of transcription and recombination not all that different from genetic material. Take the view that genetic material is just a kind of information and there is no difference at all. In that view the diversity of information has in fact increased.

It is up to us to make it worth the cost.

It's a vicious circle. We can sacrifice the earth to benefit our health and longevity; but we still get everything from the Earth, and an impoverished Earth means shorter, unhealthy human lives.
In the end, I'm not sure it matters if he was right. At some point, all of the events that made up the Colombian exchange were going to happen. What does matter is that it has happened and we need to find a way to deal with the effects in a way that benefits the Earth and its inhabitants.

Name: Matt Hammer
Comments: It's not only about an impoverished biosphere. The columbian exchange cut off the development of dozens of distinct and flourishing cultures, philosophies, and systems of thought in the Americas and Africa. Their surviving writings are often beautiful and always meaningful. I don't know whether it was a good or a bad thing, but the impoverishment of the cultural sphere also has to be considered.

Name: Jacob Golden
Comments: Well John, your closing questions are fascinating, and hard to answer. I would argue that the Colombian Exchange was ultimately a good thing for humanity. I allowed humans to develop new technologies, more quickly. And if we were to use these newly developed resources to their extent we could ultimately correct or even reverse the more distressing side-effects of the Colombian Exchange. We as humans just need to open our eyes and see what is best for us all, not just as individuals. DFTBA!

Name: NalvicReviews
Comments: The issue with the introduction of potatoes to the Irish is that it was an English-enforced monoculture in Irish agriculture. Prior to the introduction of potatoes to Ireland the Irish had a diet that was diverse than potatoes. The potato was introduced by the English to Ireland because it could turn them the greatest profit and nutritionally sustain a population on a single crop versus a variety of food sources as was used beforehand. Potato monoculture was a major factor in the later famine.

Name: Olivier L'Italien
Comments: But the renaissance was more than an artistic revolution. You guys said it yourself in the beginning of the video. So why attribute the renaissance to the money... that then paid for the arts? Ive always been taught that the renaissance was attributed to the rediscovery of the Greek philosophies. One revolutionary thought in particular was the idea that knowledge is within us all (See Meno from Plato). This meant that, if well trained, even a peasant could make valuable discoveries. Christians liked this idea too, translating it into We are in the image of God. His knowledge is within us. We are creators, like God. Maybe for this renaissance was just a vintage art trend in the eyes of the Aristocrats, but what about the thinkers (See Cusa, Kepler, Leibniz).

Comments:
This whole renaissance 're-discovery' thing, sounds very dodgy.  Everything else seems to be in tiny fragments of ruins, except the greek and roman stuff has been immaculated preserved for millennia.  And, its much wierder than lots of other 'paganism'.  Wierder usually equates to more modern.   

Its also kin of contrary to the colonising crusades, inquisitions, witchunts and 'reformations' of the seemingly relatively-believable stories of humanity's recent past.  It seems we can see when these factions were seperate and at odds, and the not-so-holy not-even-roman empire maps show this visually and clearly.

Maybe 'antiquity' was never completely lost and re-discovered and isn't so ancient after all?

Just as all but the deeply sinister and O-cult Oxford and Cambridge uni-verse-cities now admit, that the 'new' world was not discovered for the first time by Columbus and co, that the 'new' world was just temporarily out of touch with the 'old' world.

Maybe the old world was reformed by the secular-science priest class, by the likes of Newton, Rousseau, Voltaire and others, the progress of which may have been to the approval of the (holy roman) empire and its med-evil book-burning, his-story re-writing, mythology-rewriting and child-molesting priest class.  Go back further, if we could, and we might see how the bourgeoisie leapt into their abstract explorations and left 'paganism' behind.

What kind of spoken, or unspoken, deal went on whereby the humanists kind of have free mental-reign as the empire of terror devoured the flesh and spirit of the people from all other 'angles'?

"Now that we've conquered you, bourgois pontificators," said the Habsburg emperor to the finally-acquired elasticated-puppet-string pretend republics of England, France and Rome "you can have your abstract waffle, your greek freak geek stuff, your hell-en-ism, middle caste trinkets, Aragon superiority arrogance and comfort in the money pyramid social status.  Butt question the bankhers, question the authority of govern-ment, and we'll give you a stake in that (snigger), question your own silly sciences or question our his story, especially egypt, and you'll go the way of the Incas.  Give unto Wofsheyeld what is due unto Wofscheyeld.  Blame the Romans.  Helen was millennia ago, Egypt was milennia ago.  Capiche"

"Yes Osiris, err, Sire"

"That's better, and make that Horus a silent 'H' while you're at it, the crew-see-fiction when they sing a c-horus.  Delete it in future dictionnaries if the fish-kids aren't schooled to forget.  And ban sex-talk, we don't want them noticing the resurrection uis a spelling of the re-erection now do we?"

"Got it.  You can have your age-of-weason abswact science, no more roman, celtic, helen-istic, babylonian or egyptian.  Stick with the mary story fairy story if the ask about 'notre dame de Paris'!"

Maybe it went down this way, maybe it didn't and the abswact age-of-reason bourgeoisie are just a bunch of spelled dumb-asses lost in abstract thinking.  Half the bosses I ever worked for, and my own parents fit the latter description.  The others kinda felt like they couldn't avoid the abstract nonsense they had to speak to their peers.

They'd have made a right mess on their own, but certainly nothing like the evil mess we see.

Name: Karel Dole?el
Comments:
If youre here to learn about Renaissance, dont even bother. (Theres a brief overview between 1:08 and 3:11, but thats basically it.) I dont know what I expected, but this video is nothing but political agenda and sophism. Instead of actually talking about what Renaissance was, 80% of the video is devoted to who should be given credit for it. (Or whether it even happened?) And the presented arguments are downright absurd.

"Renaissance was funded by the trade with the Ottoman Empire?" Trading means an exchange of goods and services, not philanthropy. The money (and alum), that was brouht back to Italy, was exchanged for the Venetian textiles and Milanian weapons that you mentioned and wasnt therefore owed to anyone. Venice and Milan werent rich because of some "Ottoman benevolence", but because of their labor and ingenuity to produce high quality products. They got rich on their own merits.
And even if it was, even if Leonardo da Vincis patrons werent the Medici but some rich Ottoman family, his works are still credited to him alone. Renaissance is defined by the arts and intellectualism, not the money. A lot of people in a lots of places had gold, but only one place had the artists to produce Renaissance art. 
You might as well talk about how Chinese culture should be credited to Europeans, because "the Chinese got rich by trading on the Silk Road". It would be an equally absurd argument.

"The Muslim world was the source of many of the writings Renaissance scholars studied?" So lets give them credit for their own inventions and contributions? How is it relevant to Renaissance? The Sumerians invented the Cuneiform writing, should we give them credit for Romeo and Juliet? Should the Ottoman culture itself be credited to the Greek authors they studied? Everyone was influenced by someone.
In fact, if were gonna go down that road, doesent the fact that we are talking about Greek authors make it a pretty much pointless discussion? What exactly is the "added value" here? Preserving of knowledge? Transcribing? That doesent make it a "source of the writings the Renaissance scholars studied". The "source" were the Greek authors who wrote them.
 
"Renaissance didnt happen because most people didnt know about it?" I dont even know what was the crazy idea behind that one. The buildings, sculptures and literature defining Renaissance exist, which in fact proves its existence. History isnt a popularity contest. 
Was Europe enlightened? Yes, it was. Although I never heard anyone claim that the entire European population, presumably including newborn babies, was engulfed by humanism. Thats just a crazy straw man.  But Im pretty sure more people saw a Ranaissance building than the Battle of Hastings.
And when Johaness Guttenberg invented the printing press in 1440, a lot of Renaissance literature got in the hands of ordinary people shortly thereafter. (But I guess that didnt make the cut.)

Name: Puppe Reign
Comments:
Two and a half minutes into the video and I simply can't go on.

Painting certain biblical figures over and over again doesn't necessarily mean the artists were doing so out of devotion to Catholicism; they were most often commissioned, downright forced, or trying to appeal to nobles in order to earn more for their efforts. Artists then weren't celebrated like they are today, and those who chose this path were considered failures (at least until they were taken under a great mentor's wing and had produced some renowned pieces). In families with a certain kind of history they were expected to carry on with their legacy, which with high regard included professions such as becoming a blacksmith or banker. We may still apply some of their ideals in our daily life, but generally the world is very different now to how it was five centuries ago - unless you stay in Florence, of course.

Name: Frederick Torres
Comments: The Islamic Golden Age was entirely fueled through the study of ancient Greek texts, with incremental improvements, vastly built upon in Europe during the Renaissance. The Islamic world was already on a downward slope intellectually by the 11th Century due to the influence of Al Ghazali and his opinion of heretical pagan Greek texts. These same texts which are the heart and soul of any of these sciences and had largely been lost to Europe until the Renaissance. Such as Plato, largely reduced to a fragmentary text of Timaeus for a thousand years in the Latin world. Before we get carried away with crediting Islam with the success of Europe, it's its important to remember where their own success was indebted, and to keep account of who exactly it was that paved the way to splitting the atom and going to the moon. So yes, the Renaissance was definitely a thing, with the proliferation of translations made available through the Medici and Marsilio Ficino and the development of the Gutenberg Press magnifying the already immense libraries developing across Europe and ensuring the preservation of classical literature definitively forever.

Comments: I'm here because the test  will measure whether I am an informed, engaged, and productive citizen of the world, and it will take place in schools and bars and hospitals and dorm rooms and in places of worship. Name: Darth Mark
Comments: The printing press was also developed in the 15th century. Then a guy called Aldus Manutius in Italy started printing a ton of books about his favourite things, such as the Greeks, and his press is one of the reasons that Europe suddenly started learning about and nerding out over the Greeks. He even invented a new, slanted font to try and pack more letters onto a page. Because he was in in Italy, it got called italics. In any case, the sudden increase in the availability of books (from Aldus and various others) was critical in spreading ideas, such as Copernicus's heliocentric model of the solar system.

Comments: To be fair about Copernicus, it meant a lot less back in those days to be both a lawyer and a doctor compared to now. Also - still true today - anyone with a spot of intelligence and perseverence can basically do the work of a lawyer.. In general, although Copernicus and other famous named did make important discoveries, we should remember there was so much more of the basics of our world to discover if you applied yourself to exploring it critically. It was not like today.

Name: Mark Langridge
Comments:
Lots of people taking this out of context. He's arguing (he says arguing, not definitely proving) that Renaissance "wasn't a thing" because we teach it as if it was a singular event that took place over a short timespan, such as the French Revolution, or World War II, or widespread adoption of the internet (this is far more profound than you may realize.)

The Renaissance didn't occur like this points in time, these historical events. It was more of a time period than a historical event. That's all he's saying, and it can't really be argued. John *clearly states* that he isn't suggesting the events of the Renaissance never happened. Think about it, though. Most of the famous figures of the Renaissance didn't even know each other.

And yes, just because very few people actually experienced the Renaissance as it was happening, doesn't mean it isn't important. However, John never claimed that, never even hinted at it. The Renaissance was enormously important to history, especially art history.

It's much like how the post impressionist painters were not a cohesive movement. In fact, post impressionism was only named as such after the "movement" had ended and the artists had died.

Name: Froehlig Girlz
Comments: Wha? You left out the GLASSBLOWERS?  Seriously, how did it all end up in Venice? How could they afford anything from the beginning? Their bootstraps were glassblowing skills - the Renaissance was the invention of selling skills, or rather, market domination without enormous resources. (Japan just about emulated that c. 1960.). You can't say Italian without glass... Oh, and opera....  The Renaissance birthed HARMONY, and meter as we know it, for everyone who went to mass.And no, Palestrina wasn't shooting for political upheaval.... Church musicians never get credit.... *sigh*

Name: Zebedee Hill
Comments: I have to disagree with you on the argument that the renaissance didn't happen. You're looking at one point of the renaissance, also bring the most popular, in the arts. You consistently talk about how the arts only affected the upper class, which it did, but neglect to talk about the effect that it had. That art brought the idea of being human. That humans weren't put on earth to do God's bidding, instead you could aspire to be something, instead of scholars arguing about how many angels can sit on a pinhead, they asked questioned about why humans where, well, humans. What made a human, why a human made certain moral decisions. If we take your example of how long the renaissance lasted - 1400s to 1600s - then it would include the reformation, where people asked the moral decisions of the church. You witnessed history by seeing people dismantle and climb the Berlin wall, well these people witnessed the divide of a religion, and I think that is relatively important to history.

Name: Peter Kauffner
Comments: Yes, the peasant behind the plow might not have seen a difference between the Middle Ages and the Renaissance. But every major intellectual of the period remarks on the fact that he lived in a new age of possibilities that is distinct from what went before. The big change was that it was OK to be happy and enjoy being alive. Medieval writers were severely depressed by modern standards and saw worldly life simply as a preparation for the afterworld. Many people assume that it was classical science that was "reborn" in the Renaissance. But the reception of classical science happened in the twelfth century during the High Middle Ages.  What the Renaissance learned from classical writers was humanism and an appreciation of art.

Name: billhammerjr
Comments:
The idea that there was not a Renaissance is provocative but it does not help in the understanding of the ideas that were expressed in that time time and place.  Many of which are noted in these threads.  There was no mention of the European renaissance which picked up these ideas and spread it across Europe in which were the antecedents of the Reformation and the Enlightenment can be traced.  I think the 1% that were in the renaissance realized their was something happening they were a part of.  It's hard to imagine Lorenzo Valla was not writing to the 1%.  Something else to consider is what was the capacity of the people to absorb the Renaissance.  In a medieval Europe what percentage could read with the Church largely controlling education.  And the growth of a middle class craft class . . . I don't think dismissing the era over it's length in time is helpful to understanding the period or the transmission of it's memes.

A simple comparison is the 60s.  Were people walking around in 1969 USA saying "Hey it's the decade of the 60s?  I don't think so.  But they thought they were living through an exceptional era.  And for better or worse we refer to the era as the 60's.

Name: Annabel Noordzij
Comments: One thing that is majorly misunderstood is that the Renaissance did not introduce the 'lost' Greek knowledge. Texts on Aristotle and other Greek writers had already been re-introduced in Europe starting in the 11th century. Next to that, it wasn't purely Greek knowledge, but a combination of ancient Greek and medieval Arabic knowledge. People like to say that the Renaissance was a scientific revolution, but it was merely a continuation of the scientific climate which had persisted in the universities for centuries. The biggest change was that science became more secularized, as in it was no longer exclusive to the clergy to study science, not that those scientist became less Christian. The Renaissance can best be described as a cultural movement, since there's clear evidence of changes in the artistic and literary spheres, but not as a standalone scientific movement, nor the start of any huge social changes.

Name: Minotaur Mangum
Comments: Aristotle was wrong about everything? His Logic is still the gold standard, and his Poetics is still an essential and influential work of literary criticism. His view of the psyche is arguably superior to that of modern thinkers like Locke and Descartes.

Name: dyn01234567
Comments:
It seems to me the John is treating the renaissance like and event by comparing it to the fall of the Berlin wall. The Renaissance was an era, not an event and in that sense it did happen.

It's true that the average person didn't see it's effects, but that can be said of many eras as they happened. The medieval era didn't effect the average person all that much either, because very few people lived in a castle, was a knight or had any impact on the feudal social structure. But castles still got built, knights existed and the feudal system ruled the land. They're the things we remember because they left a a greater mark on the landscape and influenced our systems of governance more than a guy growing turnips in a field.

Name: Johnny Luken
Comments:
1. The Eastern Roman/Byzantine Empire existed unbroken for almost 3,000 years from the time of the Renaissance, extending back to the time of the Ancient Greeks. Most of the works of the Ancient Greeks, along with people with the ability to interpret them, existed there for the duration.

2. Christian scholars existed throughout Europe even in the depths of the Dark Ages (beautiful handcrafted Latin scriptures exist in Ireland dating as far back as AD 500), as Christianity had been able to rapidly spread across Europe even as the Western Roman Empire faltered.

3. GraecoRoman artifacts still physically existed and could be found throughout the territories of the former Roman Empire up to time of the Renaissance.

4. Large, stable and prosperous kingdoms had started to naturally coalesce in Europe from AD 800-1200, mapping quite closely to modern European nations from this point

5. When the Renaissance occurred in Europe, there was no Muslim correlate

All in all, I don't think Muslims had much at all to do with the European renaissance.

Name: Amanda C.
Comments: Just because the Renaissance artists created works of art depicting religious figures doesn't imply that they themselves were religious. At the time, artists had a clientele consisting mostly of the Pope and the clergy in general, because they were obviously quite wealthy compared to common people, so religious depictions was kinda their thing and they had very specific requests. The Catholic Churh saw art as a way of displaying wealth and power, so this was quite a benefit for the artists. However, many artists, including da Vinci, created (not only) religious works of art, but sometimes tried to incorporate their own (non-religious) ideas, via symbolism, which the clergy didn't fancy much and had not so pleasant results.

Name: Tim Petzold
Comments: A couple of things. The video makes an effort of painting the Renaissance as a result of Arabic influence on Europe. There is certainly a good deal of intellectual benefit that Europe received from the Islamic world. But the reception of thinkers like Aristotle and Avicenna happened in the 13th century, the time of the scholastic tradition more so than the humanist. Btw, Aristotle had been studied well before that, as his logical works were the focus of study throughout the Middle Ages, thanks to Boethius and Porphyry. The 12th century saw the gain of his whole corpus. But it was the re-discovery of Plato and other writers of Greco-Roman culture like Cicero and Livy that spurred the thought of the Renaissance. And that brings me to another note, there is a different way that the Islamic world is credited with igniting the Renaissance. The Ottoman sacking of the Byzantine world and the fall of Constantinople caused their thinkers to flee to Latin Europe bringing their texts with them. It's easy to see why something this politically incorrect did not get mentioned though.

Name: Twisted Pixel
Comments: saying the Renaissance wasn't really a thing because of the length it lasted (~200) is like saying the classical age(~800), or the bronze age (~1100, or ~500, ~300, ~300 depending on how you look at it) wasn't really a thing either.  I think you're just missing the fact that the "ages" are simply summaries of a time, before something amazing changed everything. I mean, i guess maybe you're arguing about all the incredible developments discovered in this time should each be their own defining categories, which is a fair argument, but think of what that would do to the industrial age, or frankly, any age after.  humans are compounding at an exponential rate, thanks to, a large part, the Renaissance.  The relative peace and prosperity that followed the middle ages is what ushered in this age, and the difference of such, has ushered in every age before it.  The ultimate point i'm trying to make (of which i recognise you touched on, but i don't feel you gave it enough credit) Is that ages are not defined by their accomplishments, but in their stabilities.

Name: Benjamin Dixon
Comments: While I can appreciate your point regarding the rennaissance not being an actual thing I have to disagree. While it didnt enlighted the world as a whole, or even europe, it led to the reintroduction of widespread republicanism and the study of the humanities. For example, Thomas Jefferson and many of the founding fathers of America - as well as the not so successfull French revolution - were proufoundly influenced by the Renaissance/enlightenment. It wasn't a singular moment that profoundly changed history, but I have to argue that it was a series of events which had a tremendous impact on the future of European peoples and nations. To appease younger me, ill quote Jellow Biafra from the song "Chickenshit conformist" on the Dead Kennedys "Bedtime for Democracy" album : "Any real change takes more time and effort than changing channels on the TV set." Love your videos, and your... mostly politically and ideologically neutral perspective.

Comments: I object to your reasoning that the Renaissance can be argued to "not have happened" simply because it was not consciously happening across the entire population. As a historian I legitimately have never heard the school of thought that a movement did not happen because it was not actively happening to or affecting absolutely everyone. Name: Scott Butler
Comments: None of his points successfully refute the existence of the Renaissance. The rise in humanism, even if only in a small segment of the population, still led to changes in political and religious thought that ultimately gave us the Age of Discovery, which via Western Imperialism gave us globalization, and the Enlightenment, which in turn gave us modern democracy and secularism. Whether you think those are good or bad points does not lower their importance. The Renaissance wasnt a single point that immediately changed everything for everyone and it never claims to be that. It was a revolution in thought and culture that led ultimately to discoveries in science, of continents, of changes in human expression, and even was part of a chain of trends that led to a complete transformation of global society.

Name: aurelius
Comments:
An Open Letter to Mr. Green & Co.

Dear Mr. Green and Company,

I love this series. I love Crash Course. I platonically love you all.

But this episode, though. I don't care for it.

See, the Renaissance existed as much as any other period of history exists: in our minds, as a handy reference tool. If the Inquisition exists, so too does the Renaissance. If the Golden Age of Islam exists, so too does the Renaissance. If the Silk Road exists, so too does the Renaissance.

You describe the Renaissance, near the end of the video, as "a lot of mutually interdependent things that occurred over centuries." Yes - which is to say, it's a thing. It's a thing that helps historians group similar ideas over a period of time. Saying the Renaissance didn't exist is like saying Ancient China (for instance) didn't exist because it, too, is a lot of mutually interdependent things that occurred over centuries."

Eurocentrism sucks, but that doesn't mean everything European that was positive should be minimalized. If you're going to - rightfully! - denounce European violence, so too must you not minimalize Middle Eastern violence or Asian violence. (For example: The Mongol Conquests killed at *least* 40,000,000 people - possibly more like 70,000,000! - but the Mongols get endless praise and a comical throwback in every episode.)

I still do love this series. And Crash Course. And, platonically, you.

Best wishes,
Me

Name: Emily H
Comments:
your right that the term "renaissance" is a label that we, in the present, give to a set period of time in history (from the THIRTEENTH century to the 16th) but that doesn't mean it isn't a valid concept. 
Its just an umbrella- term for; a popular style of thinking, fashion sense, series of events, works of art and much more that existed/happened during said given period of time. 
When someone says the word "renaissance" you automatically (to a good degree subconsciously) get a general idea of all these things in your head. Language is such a limited means of communication and expression, (and the human mind itself is pretty finite) we need to make it as easy as possible to (albeit) roughly refer to things, such as slices of time in history.

The word exists for us today as a quick and concise tool of reference, rather than belonging to the age itself.

Name: Matthew Wright
Comments: While I love Crash Course, here I struggle to understand John's argument toward the end of the video. I understand his saying that we shouldn't think of the Renaissance as a single period but I think he kind of attacks a straw man here. Only the ill-informed would say that the Renaissance was an "instant-on" era where suddenly Europe becomes magically reinterested in the classical world. Once you study it you realize that "renaissance" thinkers were spread apart geographically and chronologically, but that is much the same as the classical world (in fact, much further spread apart chronologically than many renaissance thinkers). So I guess I just disagree with John because i don't think anyone here is saying what John thinks they're saying; i.e. "the renaissance happened at once everywhere and it was magical."

Name: SFS Financing
Comments:
Strongly disagree. 
Renaissance was an "Age". Ages never have set dates for starting or ending. The Stone, Bronze, and Iron Ages don't have set dates. The Industrial Revolution does not have a set date. But, they all happened and were important.

For me, the true start of the Renaissance was the printing of the Gutenberg Bible. Printing is what made the Renaissance so NEW. Without printing, there would have been no market for maps. Without a market for maps, locations and routes would have been kept secret by ship captains, like they always were.  It was the free flow of information that spurred on science, exploration, and the Reformation.

Name: Bill McHale
Comments:
Linking Aristotle to "The Renaissance" is a bit a historical.  His writings were recovered in the late 12th and earlth 13th centuries and played a central role in Scholasticism, especially the thinking of Thomas Aquinas.   Now, if we want to talk about Plato's writings, you have a stronger case.  Its also true that Plato's writings seemed to have a strong influence on Copernicus, Galileo and others.  

The strongest case against the Renaissance as a distinct break from the past, is that for that idea to work, you need to paint the high and late medieval period (which the Renaissance overlaps with) as being eras of ignorance (i.e., the long outdated view of them as "the Dark Ages".).  In reality, it was a period when Universities were founded, achievements were being made in engineering, farming, philosophy, etc. (Don't believe me?  The Roman's wouldn't have been able to build a Gothic Cathedral... even with concrete).
