Name: megan brown
Comments: I didn't entirely agree with one point you made. You said that that the proof that the writers and scholars were secretly not religious was the Art they painted. However I don't think that is substantial proof because of how big the religious power was at the time. Religious authorities, including the pope had the money and were prepared to pay a lot for religious Art. Paint was expensive and as a Artist like Leonardo or Michael Angelo you could guarantee a lot of money for a religious commission. Any other subjects and they probably would have died poor people who we would not have heard of today. I'm not an Historian, so there may be other evidence however a big point that is hard to miss is the fact that despite the rise in Humanism and Secularism, denying your faith in Religion at that time would have still meant a death sentence. Even Martin Luther who never denied his faith, infact lived by it strictly was arrested and excommunicated and perhaps would have suffered even worse if he had not fled. With that constant threat who would openly deny religion? So it's definitely possible that writers and scholars hid their beliefs. We have evidence in their quotes and writings which insinuates a lack of belief. Their interest in the natural world and curiosity for science and questions prove that they were not following and believing in Religion in quite the same way, considering Religion was supposed to have  all the answers, this just proves they were thinking independently from it, so who knows what conclusions they came to. For example Michael Angelo said "faith in oneself is the best and safest course" better than the faith in the divine? I'm not saying its proof but surly opens questions, that we can't just slam down and say obviously they were religious because the world back then did not have the same freedoms that we have now.

Name: Sally Lee
Comments:
The problem with calling The Renaissance not a thing, is you have to define a thing is. And to do that you have to define the context in which something is a thing. John Green did neither of these while calling The Renaissance not a thing. 

To illustrate this, let us look at the example of classical music. By this I do not mean all of the music composed between the Medieval ages to modern time following the Western European tradition. I am referring to the classical period of music, lasting between 1750 and 1820, comprised most notably of Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven. 

1. Much like the first wave thinkers and artists of Renaissance, Haydn did not intend on starting a new thing. He didnt make the conscious decision to end Baroque music and start something new called classical music. Neither Mozart nor Beethoven acknowledged that they were leading a whole new movement in music
2. Most of the population did not enjoy this music and were unaware this change during the classical period, much like how the peasants were unaware of the arrival of The Renaissance
3. Furthermore, the three notable classical composers have greatly different sounds in their work. In fact, most people cant even hear how the latter composers were influenced by their predecessor(s). At least artists of The Renaissance had a common springboard for aesthetics.

So, is the classical period a thing? It very much is!

You might point out that the classical period lasted only 70 years, whereas The Renaissance lasted 200 years, making it easier for the classical period to be a thing. However, consider the predecessor of the classical period  Baroque. The Baroque period lasted just under 200 years, and it is very much a thing as well. In fact, we still refer to music composed during this period as Baroque music.

The thing is, most periods and movements in art, literature, music and architecture were not meta enough to have named or defined itself during its own time. These periods were defined and named by scholars much later, for the sole purpose of being able to discuss them with ease. If I didnt have the phrase The Renaissance, Id have to refer to it as that period between 14th and 17th centuries in Europe, when art, architecture, philosophy etc of initially Italians, but later also other Western Europeans, became focused on Greek and Roman aesthetics and philosophy etc. And this long phrase is probably not as encompassing as the simple term The Renaissance.

Therefore, The Renaissance is very much a thing.

Name: Aeric Cinema
Comments:
Your point about our projection of a false narrative upon history is EXTREMELY accurate.

However, defining the Renaissance as "not a  thing" because of the fact that it seems to be a series of many, interdependent "things" that happened over centuries and therefore built up as a "sequence", making the Renaissance "not a thing", is debatable.

When you see into any event of history, into any "thing" (a war, for example), it often becomes evident that the "thing" is not actually just one single sequence, but is in fact a series of many interdependent elements, all happening on a microscopic scale.

The difference with the Renaissance is that it is a "thing" that happened with interdependent elements happening on a MACROSCOPIC scale.

So the Renaissance is not one flowing event in history, as it was previously perceived to be. But it is an event, like events such as war, that happened as a result of elements happening on a microscopic scale to create something that we can observe on a macroscopic scale.

Comments: Wealth is definitely a supporting factor, but there has to be more. There's and underlying reason, social evolution and enlightenment. Which comes from human curiosity and contact with a broader world. The competition between Italian states also fostered this, bc governments in high competition must try harder to justify there pretenses to greatness. So human curiosity is not suppressed as usual, bc it can be inconvenient. And when it was inconvenient they in power reacted as usual. And they did understand themselves as living in a new era, guilds for example also participated in "the renaissance". Renaissance men where highly respected in their time. Another part of the renaissance was republicanism, the state as a work of art, they celebrated in the squares with fireworks ever more elaborated, there was a spirit of the times. At least in cities, it touched everyone. So did the reaction, Sovanarola. So I really don't think it canconsidered as a mostly "ivory tower" phenomena.

Name: Kanishka Ray
Comments: No one is saying that the Humanists were atheists or non-religious, many weren't and continued to produce religious themed art, but the secular nature of the Florentine Renaissance is unmistakable and undeniable in its move away from religion for the sake of religion and the representation of humanness (and divinity itself) in a more realistic and technically accurate human form. Without this secularity, there would have been no possiblity of backlash from a relgious tyrant like Savonarola. The Northern Humanists on the other hand were more religiously focused and determined to reform a Church that in their view had lost its way.

Name: Supadubya
Comments: Actually, the discoveries of the Renaissance DID affect more than just the top 5%.  It affected nearly all city or town-dwellers (sorry, but for most of human history VERY LITTLE affected the farming/rural populace except for disruptive wars- thus pointing to their lives being unaffected is rarely a valid argument for the non-existence of any change...)  Not only were there re-discoveries of important architectural concepts by Europeans (the neo-Grecan and Roman styles were more than just superficial- architects rediscovered building concepts making much more impressive buildings possible) which led to better public buildings- thus affecting a large portion of all city-dwellers, there were also improvements in methods of well-construction, machinery and harvesting of wind and water power, and animal husbandry techniques (one of the few changes that *did* affect farmers- although much more significant changes would occur during the later "Enlightenment").  Most importantly, the rise of individualism and rationalism changed the way politics were conducted to at least a small extend (although money, power, and violence were still predominant), thus indirectly affecting every segment of the populace...

Comments: Why people think of history as a simple string of events? Historical periods are much complex and looooong term than simple events such as a geographic discoveries, wars or revolutions.So the renaissance was a thing, because as you said, it was "a lot of mutually interdependent things that ocurred over centuries", and let me add, in a particular part of the world: Europe (mostly Italy but also Western and Central Europe.) Name: RonaldReaganRocks1
Comments: I see people agreeing that periodization is bad, and I see people correctly stating that the Renaissance did happen even if it only affected a certain slice of the population, and only a certain slice of learning. If you can prove that something actually happened and that it was markedly different from the time period before it, then it existed. The Renaissance definitely happened, and it was definitely a time of shifting in the arts, philosophy, and the humanities in general. It is definitely the time period in which the classical arts of Greece and Rome were rediscovered and the sensibilities of the humanities definitely shifted away from medieval scholasticism and other medieval sensibilities. What is undeniable, and what I think John Green is getting at, is that our classification of a time period is an oversimplification. I don't know if historians even are intending to deceive, or if their classification is as nuanced as it should be, and the way that classification is taught comes across as oversimplified, because we are trying to teach relatively stupid people things, and they need things simplified for them. Even if the Renaissance only affected 5% of the population and didn't affect all disciplines of society, it still happened. I can see what John is saying: if you walked up to a farmer during this time period, and asked him if he agreed that he was living in the Renaissance, he might have no idea what you are talking about, especially if neither farming nor any of the aspects of his life had changed. Periodization gives too much of an impression that all things changed in a period and were all encompassing, as if every single thing had changed from one era to another. It is better to think of periods as trends that became en vogue and popular, and then faded out. While these are on a much smaller, less significant scale, I have lived through the grunge era of the '90s and the emo era of the 2000s, and it is easier to think of periods like that. Did every aspect of my life change? No, but some of the more conspicuous things like music and fashion did. So did some of the sensibilities, philosophies, beliefs and pieces of technology. However, I am largely the same person, and people are generally the same from period to period, if they live that long.

Name: John Mars
Comments:
Every historian nowadays knows that periodization is wrong. The Renaissance was much less a "historical period" and more of an intellectual and artistic revolution that happened in the course of three centuries. One cannot say that "It did not happen" because quite simply it's effects were immediately felt in the scientific and intellectual world. For example Erasmus was invited to the court of the Holy Roman Emperor as a councilor, Dante and Cervantes became celebrities only a few years after their deaths, Shakespeare was read by the Elizabethan nobility, the frescos and statues in the churches were open for all too see. True, the effects of the Renaissance would not mature until the 16th century, but arguably by then the European world was already ready to leave both classical civilization for good and go towards an "Age of Enlightenment". Thus while the Renaissance was not an event like a battle, it was certainly an event in intellectual and artistic history that had very little to do with outside sources such as Muslim or Theological writings and more to do with the professionalization of secular sciences and arts.


Also, I'm a leftist but sorry John Green but even I can't accept this revisionist history that the Ottomans somehow aided to the coming of the Renaissance. If anything the Ottomans were the reason why the Italian Renaissance declined. Most of the trade exports of the Italian city-states went to central and western Europe. The prime materials for this trade to be possible came entirely from the mediterranean through the Indian Spice trade. The Venetians and Genoans facilitated this trade by way of their Greek colonies in the Aegean and Ionian seas. This trade firstly abruptly ended with the fall of Constantinople, which then was followed by the almost total territorial loss of their colonies by the Ottomans barring them completely from the Spice trade. Hence the incentive to discover India and the journey of Columbus.

Well, it's not a short event analogous to the fall of the wall. Multiple events taking place across several centuries is simply the definition of an era, which is what the Renaissance is usually seen as anyway. So a better analogy would be comparing it to the industrial revolution, and that definitely happened.
Besides, the idea of rapidly spreading news, technology and abundance to lower socio-economic classes is an entirely new idea, since even Gutenberg's printed bible was useless to illiterate people. For example,High and Late medieval times also didn't dramatically change the standard of living for most feudal serfs across Europe when compared to the Dark Ages, since the difference between getting your farm pillaged by hungry crusaders rather than some warlord was small.

Comments:
If we follow that logic, then Antiquity, Middle Ages, or Modern Times did not exist either. I mean the people living in Ancient Rome did not think "We live during the age of Antiquity." And those witnessing the fall of Rome did not think "Owe shucks... Antiquity is over. We now enter the Dark Ages." Those are all eras defined by European historians to help them understand their past. Of course, we could define other eras. Of course, the changes brought by Renaissance did not change everything. Of course they were not the result of spontaneous generation and benefited from the contributions coming from other civilisations. However, Renaissance is still a thing for us, and that's all that counts.

And for those complaining about euro-centrism : too bad for you, but there is no human civilisation yet. There are several human civilisations. It just occurs that the Western civilisation still dominate the world. The problem is not the way we understand our history, the problem is that you have (more or less willingly) accepted our periodisation even though it was made for european/western history. The Middle Ages make no sense for India. It is the work of historians from the other civilisations to propose their own periodisation that would fit the history of their own civilisation.

Name: DR ILTIZA
Comments: The first University of the worldwas Nalanda University in India. The seat of Buddhist learning. Historical sources indicate that the University had a long and illustrious life which lasted almost continually for 800 years from the fifth to the twelfth century CE. It was a completely residential university with over 2,000 teachers and 10,000 students. The profound knowledge of the Nalanda teachers attracted scholars from places as distant as China, Korea, Japan, Tibet, Mongolia, Turkey, Sri Lanka and South East Asia.Itwas later abandoned and ruined owing to the raids and persecutionby Hindus (Brahmin) Rulers andinvaders likeHuns and Sakas. Al Azhar in Cairo (972 CE), Bologna in Italy (1088 CE) and Oxford in the United Kingdom (1167 CE )had been founded before the destruction of Nalanda.

Name: Dietrich Hoefer
Comments:
I would love to hear everyones opinion in the idea that it was not just wealth that allowed the Renaissance to emerge.
While certainly trade did bring wealth and information, I think it would be the fact that this wealth and information was able to exist in City-States that allowed the biggest change. Without the existence of smaller 'nations' (appropriate word?), the effects/profits of trade would have been diffused to almost nothing. As well, the information that was 'rediscovered' was heavily focused on the ideas of individualism and specialization (economic, artistic, and otherwise). In larger nations, where governance was a greater consideration, these topics of discussion may have been simply too radical to be considered.
Wouldn't both wealth and information be considered dangerous if it was introduced into an a larger state with a more diverse population? Wouldn't larger governments have more effective means to repress these 2 things in a time when mass production/communication was not present (pre-printing press)?
There seems to be many effective arguments that can be made to the role city-states (and their social dynamic) had in bringing the Renaissance...
... but the question remains: do you agree?

Name: muk as
Comments:
Stating that the Renaissance didn't happen is an interesting point of view, but is not by any means a fact. If only 1% of the population experienced it does that mean that it didn't happen? In the 1970s when people living in the Siberian forests came in contact with the outside world they didn't know that the 2nd world war ended because they didn't know there was a war. Does that mean that the 2nd world war wasn't a thing? How many people need to be experiencing it to say that it happened. The war changed the world in many aspects as did the Renaissance. It changed it from the top down, because it changed the governments etc. Causality works in different ways, there are chain reactions. If some peasant didn't experience Michelangelo's art first hand it doesn't mean that it didn't affect him somehow.

The Renaissance didn't have a concept attached to it until many years later, but it's the same for many things. It's impossible to see anything in it's entirety while it's still happening, because it's not in it's entirety yet. People still at this day say that the Sun rises and sets while knowing that saying so is factually incorrect. Does that mean that the scientific revolution hasn't happened either, because it doesn't affect everyone everywhere in every aspect of life.

Name: Dr3adn0ught35818
Comments:
First off, thank you John Green for providing your explanation of the Renaissance. .
 Though I cannot discern whether to trust the information I obtain from your videos as true, I allow it to foster new questions of inquiry; these questions can sometimes turn into study. A student must remember that we are all taught by teachers with educated opinions, no matter the subject (yes, math too). As students and seekers of knowledge it is up to us to find and accept the truths that we may find. Crash Course has inspired new thought and perspectives that challenge my own. However, I walk away with only a thought, not a conclusion, a belief, etc. This is how I have come to understand the world: to build a scheme of world that has as many ideas and viewpoints as possible. This principle helps me understand my surroundings, nothing else. To look at the world with the idea of who is right or who is wrong can lead to suffering, anger, and bitterness; though I do not mean to say that there are not people who can be either, but it is up to the individual to decide who is right and who is wrong. Let discussion foster such thoughts so the world may grow. However I am sad that several of the strong perspectives use derisive terms. No matter how strongly you disagree, one must always respect their opponent, for they are your equal in some measure.(I apologize for any errors I am may of overlooked).

Name: sinder9737
Comments:
I know most of the comment here are freaking out about how he down plays the AMAZING GOD-GIVEN SUPER DUPER period we all call the Renaissance but i think hes just trying to convey the fact that we do over play it. Was is super cool that science and art FINALLY made a come back? heck yea. But if you really look at it that was the case in MANY places at different points in history and the Renaissance just is another one of those points but we all applaud it because it basically lead to industrialization and advancement of science instead of being crushed unlike all other periods of growing science. We remember theRenaissance because so many great ideas and objects came out of it but he is right it really just built on what came before, like every other age/era. TheRenaissance is romanticized as some amazing wellspring of all things good but really very few contributed anything of value. It was those few that are worth lauding over not the period itself.

He also is conveying that the world as a whole is part of history. Just as what we have today is largely a result of things from theRenaissance, theRenaissance is largely due to other forces including Muslim scholarship along with Greek works. We just remember Renaissance better because it was more recent and we have more paintings, writings and other stuff still around to point to and say LOOK, ISN'T THIS COOL?

He's not saying the whole section of time is irrelevant he's saying we don't look at it subjectively enough compared to most other times and that it was more a smattering of advances that took a LONG time to happen rather than some magical time we like to say it is.

TLDR; Did important things happen in theRenaissance? Absolutely,Yes. Was it a magical time where humanity was transformed? No. A small few made advances that lead to more advances but those advances were really just building upon the advances of before. (still doing it today, believe it or not)

Name: ChrisC
Comments:
1:44 -- Greek temples are ruins *now*, but not all of them were during the Renaissnace. The one you show here, the Temple of Concordia in Agrigento, Sicily (yes, but the Greeks built it) is in such good shape because it was used as a church until the mid-1700s. Its ruined condition dates from that time, not late antiquity.

The Parthenon in Athens would have been reasonable intact too, and for the same reason, becoming first a church and then a mosque. In the 17th century, during at attack on Athens by Venice, the Turks used the building for a gunpowder magazine. When a Venetian mortar shell hit it, boom. Instant ruin.

You know having been to Europe and looked at some of their self-pro ported history the Renaissance was not a big deal because these things were rediscovered. The reason they are stated to be the enlightenment is because of:
1. the printing press which made it so there was actually a reason to learn to read because books and knowledge were now accessible and...
2. People were starting to speak out against the corruption that was present in both the Catholic Church and the kings and nobility (which basically ran Europe at the time and why it roughly coincides with the Protestant reformation).
This in Europe is what marks the beginning of the "modern era" or the renaissance not simply the art and cultural rediscovery.
Basically this marks the time when conditions STARTED to allow for everyone to become "Enlightened." This of course does not mean he is wrong about the blatant Euro-centrism or the fact that as a whole they really weren't that "enlightening" to the general people, it's simply that this marks the beginning of things starting to change to allow this to happen.
The printing press marks the beginning of the "Enlightenment" and is the reason it's said to have happened, not the rediscovery of art and literature.

I would argue that any teacher who fails to teach their students what they're learning in the first 10 minutes should not be allowed to teach that subject because they themselves do not understand it well enough yet. That doesn't mean dumping facts on a sponge brain (as any modern government believes it should be), it means getting that eye sparkling "Ooohhh" moment from the student right off the bat and then proceeding to instruct the primed brain to make it's own conclusions thereafter.

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Cantino planisphere 1502, earliest surviving chart showing the explorations of Columbus to Central America, Corte-Real to Newfoundland, Gama to India and Cabral to Brazil. Tordesillas line depicted, Biblioteca Estense, Modena
The Age of Discovery is a historical period of European global exploration that started in the early 15th century with the first Portuguese discoveries in the Atlantic Archipelagos and Africa, as well as the discovery of America by Spain in 1492, and the discovery of the ocean route to the East in 1498, and by a series of European naval expeditions across the Atlantic and later the Pacific, which continued until the 18th century. It is sometimes regarded as a bridge between the Middle Ages and the Modern era, along with its contemporary Renaissance movement. European overseas expansion led to the rise of colonial empires, with the contact between the Old and New Worlds producing the Columbian Exchange: a wide transfer of plants, animals, foods, human populations (including slaves), communicable diseases and culture between the Eastern and Western hemispheres. This represented one of the most-significant global events concerning ecology, agriculture, and culture in history. European exploration allowed the global mapping of the world, resulting in a new world-view and distant civilizations acknowledging each other, reaching the most-remote boundaries much later.

Name: Jessica Lakis
Comments: Actually the term "Renaissance" WAS coined in the Renaissance by an Italian author describing the artists and architects of his day, although I'm guessing he used the Italian or Latin equivalent and not the French. As far as to whether 'regular' people experienced the benefits thereof, I'd argue that they did, especially in the long term. Certainly the artists and scholars did in the form of paying work. The tradespeople and merchants of the Italian republics certainly had an increased standard of living, plus they had some say in their own governance. There was the re-introduction of the concept of public works, such as city-planning, and water and sewage systems. The introduction of the movable-type printing press meant a freer exchange of ideas and rising literacy, as well as the founding and expansion of centers of learning, creating (better, at least) lawyers, doctors, and, importantly for Mr. Green, scholars. Away from the Italian peninsula, England experienced an increase in trade, a rising middle class, and moved away from the feudal system of government towards Parliamentary rule. In the German states, the wide-spread publication of what might have been a minor theological squabble turned into a complete split with the Roman Catholic Church. This was appealing to: a) Princes who wanted greater autonomy in their rule, and B) The average Christian who found intellectual and political empowerment in the idea that they ought to be able to read and interpret Scripture on their own without intercession from priestly classes. I'd like to add that while Mr. Green seems naturally inclined to this subject matter because his interests lie in the humanities, his tendency to use Italian (and Greek) stereotypes is troubling. When he speaks of China there are no references to Charlie Chan or depictions of people speaking in blurbs of Peking Duck, but the Italians in several of these videos are depicted as pizza tossing, cartoon turtles or mustachioed plumbers from an old video game, and speak in blurbs of olives. Why is this OK? I find this disconcerting from a White male who hails from a place where a wedge of iceberg lettuce topped with mayonnaise and yellow cheese is considered a salad. Also, if you would like to assert that there had been others who had worked with the idea of the heliocentric solar system, and there were, even in Ancient Greece, then you might want to cite some sources. Actually, cite sources in general. I'm not going to take what you say on faith because you're on the internet, which has a dubious reputation for facts.

Name: GreenbloodLady
Comments: I'm not entirely certain that you can classify the Renaissance as "not happening" simply because the vast majority of people didn't experience it at the time. Certainly your definition of what the Renaissance entails can be fluid, but just because it didn't seem terribly important at the time doesn't mean it was nonexistent. It was simply an event that lasted hundreds of years instead of a decade or two and was restricted to the elitist of the elite. It was still present, as evidenced by the fact that today, we DO marvel over many of the works of art created/rediscovered during this time period. It might not have been terribly important at the time, but we still remember it centuries later.

Name: Eric Tarnowski

I would agree with most stuff here, except your assertion that the Renaissance wasn't a "thing." I would argue that it is, because like most cases throughout history, change is not traceable to a single event. It happens gradually. You do like to mention trade, and i would agree that global trading was more important than the Renaissance, but by that same logic, trade wouldn't be important either. It may have taken a while, but Renaissance ideas DID spread around, JUST LIKE trading in the Indian Ocean. I'm sure the places taking part in global trading didn't become instantly affluent. However, it does make more sense to refer to the Renaissance as the time period in which the paradigm shift in thought and culture occurred, rather than the shift itself.

Name: Ross Alexander Scott
Comments: The problem with Green's view that the Renaissance didn't happen is that he's looking at the Renaissance as a period as opposed to a movement. Look at it as a movement, beginning in Italy and spreading out to the rest of Europe, changing architecture, art, writing, and ideology. While it did by large only affect a small portion of the population - namely the elites - this is true of almost all historical events in this time. At the end of the day it doesn't matter to a peasant in the fields who he's paying taxes to or who he swears fealty to or who he sells crops to - his life is still ruled by the sun rising and setting, to paraphrase his Green's own statement.

Name: wotan237
Comments:
Note how Mr. Green uses subtle psychology to make his shaky point. He sets up the primacy of trade, then says Copernicus most likely not only got his ideas but his very theorems from a Turk-Arab text, presumably derived from this 'trade'...also it is strongly implied that Copernicus never admitted his debts to other foreigners for his work. Somehow all this, with the notion that Aristotle was always wrong ( he wasnt, esp in marine biology ,logic, and many other areas...plus the allegation that only a fraction of the people ever even felt this so called Renaissance.( not true) ... means that there was no Renassance, but we all know the work of Copernicus arrived well after the (alleged?) start of said Renaissance. What Green omits is the unique contribution of the ecumenical council held in Florence around 1460,, and subsequest learned society that sprung up around Medici Florance. Cardinal Nicolas of Cusa helped spearhead this movement, which did indeed go on to create a larger middle class, a more numerous literate society, (book printing after 1453 exploded, but I guess Green will next claim that a Turk actually printed the Gutenberg Bible, lol) .... The Renaissance accelerated modern concepts of science and scientific knowledge gradually became much more widespread, (Kepler) infrastructure expanded, and the age of navigation and exploration coincided with the advance of the Florentine and later northern Renaissance. Mr. Green will do almost any deceptive slight on hand or mind to avoid acknowledign the validity of Eurocentric views, but he has to like it or lump it.

( To help convince us, next time actually present us with the Arab text in question that Copernicus supposedly plagiarized, then juxtapose that with a scholars direct evidence that the plagiary actually happened. But he never did this, alas, lol )

Name: X009X
Comments:
You did not talk about the invention of movable type, which proliferated and transformed the way text were produced and reproduced. Along with new printing method that enabled large reproducing of image. 15-20 millions do books were printed in the second half of the 15th century alone, which was unimaginable to the Medieval mind because books were reproduced by scribes copying a book each individual letter by hand. In these printed materials, some were religious, some were scientific, some were lighthearted comics that only focused on human interest. 
Because of the advancement of printing, the way knowledge was communicated transformed, printed materials were affordable and came in massive amount, a general readership arose in Europe during the Renaissance, and the practice of modularization made letterpress a prototype for industrialization. Clearly the printing industry served to shape the was information and knowledge were shared and spread among a large European population, now how was Renaissance not a thing?

Name: Jackson Graham
Comments:
Okay, I liked the video, but the reasoning behind the Renaissance (or lack thereof) is kind of hard to get behind.

You argue that nobody woke their kids up for the radical shift in European culture towards one based on humanism and trade. Thus, the Renaissance never happened. That's sort of the same argument as "Nobody ever woke their kids up between 1945 and 1950 and said 'We're a Global Superpower!', so thus, the rise of the US to the global stage never happened."

Just because a radical shift can't be measured in a short period of time does not mean that the shift is a natural part of the progression of history. Look at it this way: for nearly 1000 years, Europe was a hodgepodge of angry kingdoms, famine, religious fervor, and intellectual stagnation, with the remains of Greco-Roman knowledge hidden in monasteries or overseas in the Abbasid caliphate. In the mid-1450's, that changes. City-states gain ridiculous amounts of power, culture, and wealth in decades, where their contemporaries like England and the Holy Romans took 400-odd years. I'm pretty certain that qualifies as having its own name and time period.

Comments: Alright Green, your argument is really invalid and unrelated. Your basically saying that the rennassaince did not happen because it was an evolving idea, right? Well welcome to history. Of course nobody went out side and realized it was the rennansaince, because it is simply a term coined by historians. History does not happen over night, we study it liek it did, but practically everything historical event evolve. For example: sticking with the theme of European History lets talk about the Protestatn Reformation: Martin Luther did not simply post the 95 thesis and the rest of Europe was then divide. No, rather a series of events occured an leading the to development of protestant states and then the 30 years war and the Treaty of Wesphilia. Of course people did not walk outside and said, "Hey its the Protestant Reformation" or "Its the Rennasaince" because historical events sum up the world's point of view of an event, not the individual, micro perspective.

Name: Florence Kickham
Comments: what the Renaissance was has been dictated later by art historians, it is more of an abstract concept than a specific historical event. This is why un-like historical events it may not have been entirely recognised by all of the people in the time. Name: Florence Kickham
Comments: actually many of the "secular" works of the renaissance have hidden religious ideas, for instance many art historians believe that the "Birth of Venus" by Botticelli is a representation of the immaculate conception. Also the secular works of the renaissance are not denying religion they are just transitioning focus onto people and mythology. To be Catholic was not second guessed by people during the renaissance, they simply extended their beliefs rather than denying their own church.

Name: Emma Kate Laubscher
Comments: I think that the whole 'were they religious' debate can be better approached by viewing the renaissance intellectuals as individuals. The Enlightenment was marked by a rise in individualist and supposed 'free' thinking which can be viewed as one of the motivations for the (post) Modern approach to religion i.e. 'each to their own'. So, yes, some renaissance thinkers were religious and some weren't. Because they were people - just like you and me.

Name: jfdowd
Comments:
Archimedes wasn't really "doing calculus". What he was doing was using limit arguments to reach mathematical conclusions. However, his limit arguments were ad hoc and required extraordinary cleverness.

Calculus on the other hand provided a systematic method for reaching such results.

The difference is that what Archimedes considered his single greatest mathematical accomplishment is now routinely assigned as a homework problem to high school students.

That is the power of Calculus.

Name: GPlinthon
Comments:
The ''englightment'' is clearly a French-localised event with minor events in Germany and Britain. It was not any ''scientific'' movement promoting science, nor any revolutionary philosophical break-up but rather a well rehearsed propaganda by plutocratic classes trying to take full hold of French (and in extent European) affairs.

It is not accidental that the main funder of the ''French enlightment'' was the... British kings! Ask Voltaire on that how he made his money... by selling books?

Name: GPlinthon
Comments: The Renaissance - as said below was not any renaissance but a Naissance of the western world a period during which some scientific progress occured in western Europe for the first time in its history through copying the eastern roman and arabic texts - the few that were salvaged (cos westerners were illiterate up to that time and had destroyed the most...). The whole excercise had only started as a ... fashion among newly rich Venicians trying to imitate Eastern Romans...

Name: GPlinthon
Comments: The Scientific Revolution occured in Ionia where Greek philosophers first distinguished the religion, the myth and the logic without the one cancelling the other. From there on people studied science not as part of another field but as a field on its own - on the basis of observation, experiment and proof.

Name: GPlinthon
Comments:
This is also a reason that you see a huge jump in knowledge in Western Europe from 1400 to 1600 followed by a relative deceleration from 1600 to 1800 until at last the increasing industrialisation (commenced in late 1700s) and spread of literacy and paper produced the boom of 1800-2000.

Had that initial 1400-1600 boost being clearly the genuine work, there would be no 1600-1800 deceleration.

The 1400-1600 was about copying which had to be digested first to be able to produce original science.

Name: GPlinthon
Comments:
Yep! Copernicus had just copied Eastern Roman archives which were actually education material on the basis of Aristarchus' (and other ancient writers) works. The Eastern Romans (out of them it was mostly the medieval Greeks, who else!) did not pretend to re-discover things. They were building upon already established knowledge.

Recently the ''notebook'' of Newton was published... it was basically written in Greek. Not ancient. Medieval. But Newton hardly spoke Greek.. he made rought sketches...

Name: GPlinthon
Comments:
To have a REnaissance one must have something before. The reality is that north and west of Rome there was NOTHING before to be re-born.

There was no Renaissance but a Naissance. The ''Re'' prefix was added by Western Europeans to prolong their fairly short historic path.

Name: TheGovernment100
Comments: While it probably didn't have an immediate effect on daily life, it would be simplistic to say it did not exist. The individualistic ideologies that pervaded the intellectual elite, as well as the increasing decadence of the Catholic, basically paved the way for Martin Luther to pose his revolutionary views, and subsequently crash the monopoly that the Catholic had on Europue for almost 1000 years. It may have not been an immediate impact, but it still existed beyond doubt.

Name: HMCN
Comments: It's called the Ichthys, and was used as a secret symbol for Christians to identify each other during the Roman's persecution of Christians. It's called Ichthys because it's an acronym for "Jesus, Anointed, God, Saviour, Son" (in Greek), and the fish was chosen because of the numerous times fish are mentioned in the Bible. It's used as a bumper sticker nowadays and has lead to some pretty amusing parodies: some atheists have put legs on it, and put that on their cars - check them out!

I would like to argue that classifying the period from the Xth to the XIVth Century as "unenlightened" is wrong. The Renaissance and its artistic spring is not a sudden set of changes brought by wealth and the rediscovery of the Ancients. It's the culmination of the Medieval evolution of thought, science and culture. 

Also, before the Xth Century we cannot talk about "dark, unenlightened" either. We can just say that we don't know, because there's so little documentation left.

Name: blkgardner
Comments: Many of the ideas that are associated with the Renaissance actually developed later. For example, the 16th and early 17th centuries were the time of the greatest religious fanaticism. Likewise, the height of the witchcraft hysteria dates to the 16th century. Although culture was in a "upswing", there was no hard break between the late middle ages and the Renaissance.

Name: Peter Spinney
Comments: Da Vinci actually doesn't have much historical impact because he kept all his work secret.  Nobody knew about his notebooks until something like the 19th century, he never shared his scientific ideas with his contemporaries, and encrypted his notes and hid them.  So historically his impact was in the arts, despite his undeniable genius in other areas; I suppose you could also talk about his impact as an inspiration since the discovery of his notes and journals.

Name: Sophie Jane
Comments: Also, the Renaissance was not a single event. Historians have acknowledged that it was a progression over time. Jacob Burckhardt, at 19th century historian believed that the renaissance was a complete break from the 'medieval' to the 'modern,' and writer at the time of the renaissance Vasari set up a three part view of history: The Golden Age, the Dark Ages and the Present Age, separating the renaissance as a new era, not an event.

Name: Erlinion
Comments: (3 of 3) What I do agree with, though, is the scale of the renaissance presented here. It is a mistake to view it as a process of world history, as a universal "new age" compared to the medieval "darkness". It was important to European history, sure, but the Islamic world or the Chinese Empire was not affected by neither the social-economic retrogression of the European Middle Ages, nor the intellectual resurgence that followed it. It was, by all definition, a local affair.

Name: Erlinion
Comments: (2 of 3) The fact that the novelties were rarely noticed outside a small echelon of society is sad, but hardly a factor, because it was the small echelon that remained influential in posterity. The phases of art and science before the modern age rarely affected those who did not work in the intellectual field. If the renaissance was "not a thing" because it didn't affect the larger population, you could argue that the Greek classical era or the baroque era were not "a thing" either.

Name: Erlinion
Comments: (Comment 1 of 3 - darn character limit!) While I absolutely love this show, I have to strongly object the argument that the renaissance was "not a thing". First, the people involved in it (the humanist writers, for example) were definitely aware that something new was happening, or rather, something had been reinvigorated. This view is evident from their writings at the time, and was definitely not a later invention.

Petrarch referred to the era as a new age in the early Renaissance and Kant referred to the era as the Enlightenment. People were aware that things were radically different from the past.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Part 2) The Timing Problem:
First it was 1350ish to 1650ish. Then scholars found that the Carolingians and Ottonians were pretty great and labelled them "Renaissance". Then they found out that the 12th Century was pretty great so they labelled that period "Renaissance" (includes Danish Renaissance). Now 400 years of the Medieval Period is "Renaissance". So should we label all periods that were pretty good "Renaissance" or should we just admit much of the Medieval Period wasn't all that bad?

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
I completely agree that science and secularism taking over religion is important. However I would argue that began not in the "Renaissance" but in the Enlightenment (1650~1850ish) as that is when church influence begins to decline and secular ideas and solutions starts to take over. 
Also, British scholars are the ones taking the lead in the academic realm in saying that the Renaissance DIDN'T happen, and they're European.
You also point out another problem with the "Renaissance" label - time:

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: Meanwhile I and many others mark 1500ish as the beginning of the Early Modern Era. The Colombian exchange began colonization and European overseas empire, brought new resources that drastically sped up population growth. The Reformation began, followed by the Counter-reformation and the Wars of Religion, which decreased the population of Germany by as much as 30% and I believe forced scholars to focus less on religious and more on secular issues. These combined to lead into the Enlightenment.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: Quite true. That's why I (and John and many other professional historians) don't consider the Renaissance, supposedly from 1350~1650ish, to have happened. The only thing that really changed between 1350~1500, a period in the Middle Ages, was art form. Education, Classical thinking, Urbanization, and trade just continued it's slow improvement that started around 800CE. While the ending of the plague has the potential to mark the start of the period, nothing much was different after it end.

Comments: I cast my vote saying that the Renaissance has been improperly titled & regarded. I now want to go study that history for myself and see if I still agree. Thanks JG

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: As John said, the narrative behind the name "Renaissance" is that Europe was originally enlightened, then it was unenlightened and dark. Then it was re-enlightened with the a Rebirth. That narrative was begun in the 1550s by an artist and was popular 200 years ago. But the past 70 years lots of research has uncovered evidence and lent weight to the fact that the narrative is not true. To say the period was a distinct one because of art is like saying Rock&Roll marks the start of the Modern Era.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
If you look through the curriculum from the middle ages and compare it to the Renaissance, you can see it's both the Bible and Classical writings, so no abrupt change in literature. There was no abrupt architecture change outside Italy. Sculpture and paintings changed to include classical anatomy (classical) and depth perception (new invention).
But why name an entire historical period, with a blatantly connotative inaccurate name, after an art style? If it was not better, how is it a rebirth?

Name: EyeLean5280
Comments:
There was certainly a revival of classical forms literature and art. Especially art. The Late Middle Ages were still following the Gothic model and the switch over to classical proportions actually happened relatively quickly

I did not claim the average person's life became "better." Just different.

Sorry. Still not convinced. You are passionate, but my argument still contains valid points. I respect your reasons for disagreeing, but I don't get the feeling that courtesy is returned.

Name: EyeLean5280
Comments: Come off it. In my post I said 12th century when I meant 11th. A one-digit error representing one century

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
1500ish is usually taken as the end of the Middle Ages because it marks both the start of the Colombian Exchange and the Reformation.
Meanwhile the "Renaissance" start date was traditionally about 1350, after the plague ended. It's fair of scholars at the time wanted to think so, but besides the fact that's 150 years firmly in the Middle Ages, the things that were traditionally thought to be "Reborn" we now know were either not lost, even in Europe, or found between 800s and 1200s.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: These things can't really mark the end of the Middle Ages if they occurred in two thirds of the Middle Ages. Neither can wishing to be more like the Classical Period because Western Europe, as far as our records tell us, has tried to be like the Classical Period since at least the Carolingians (again) and never stopped in the Middle Ages. The 50~100 year overlap of the Middle Ages and the Renaissance (15th Century) had not the drastic changes of the Fall of Rome or the Industrial Revolution.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Except the fall of Rome was a drastic 100 year period where urban centers greatly declined due to loosing government support and upkeep, infrastructure broke down,  trade and exchange fell apart, taxation and central government ceased. A 100 year drastic period in Western Europe before things picked upped again
No such quick, drastic change took place in Western Europe during the "Renaissance". Urbanization, trade, and education picked up again with the Carolingian and never stopped.

Name: Notusedanymore
Comments: Much of it a continuation of a change but surely that can be argued its the start of the decline of the Middle Ages and the Rise of the Renaissance If not please explain, because I would similarly argue that the fall of Rome was in fact the start of the Middle Ages, as well as the end of the Classical Period. The rebirth would be the wishing to become more like the Classical empires, and therefore the architecture and literacy and overall 'high up' thinking was changed to a mimic a previous idea

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Did changes happen? Yes, since the period spans over 3 centuries.
Was there a (relatively) clear divide that marked the start of the period? No.
Did they make most people's life mostly better? No. (Not a Rebirth)
Was the transition sharp? No, over 3 centuries.
It was, quoting the video "A lot of mutually dependent thing that occurred over centuries". And it was not a Rebirth. It just continued changes that were already happening in the Mid-Late Medieval ages (urbanization, trade, etc).

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Then you must know that the focus is on timing, duration, similarities and differences, and impact.
Few of these are clear for the Renaissance (much of it a continuation of a trend started in the Mid and Late Medieval Ages), when they are much clearer for other transition periods like the 100 years fall of Rome or the Industrial Revolution.
Those that are range from good (printing press), goodish-mixed (Colombian exchange) to outright terrible (War of Religions). Where, then, was the "Rebirth"?

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: Meanwhile the War of Religions depopulated the German and Northern Italian countryside, decreasing population by as much as 30%, something Medieval wars did not do. Witch hunts and the Inquisition, incorrectly associated with the Medieval Ages, did not take place until the "Renaissance" (so much for that rebirth). Production are still controlled by guilds until well into the Enlightenment. And due to the little ice age, famine was more common in the Early and Mid Renaissance.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: As the Renaissance starts in the mid 14th Century, the fact that universities appeared in the early 11th Century means the error (universities because of the Renaissance) was actually 300 years. There's not much evidence that average literacy was any higher until the LATE Renaissance and the beginning of the Enlightenment, as until then education were split between Parish Schools and Universities. And given that more than 80% of the people worked the land, most people weren't buying stocks.

Name: EyeLean5280
Comments:
...the expansion of Mercantile capitalism all matter. They, along with other factors, combined to create a very different world for almost *everyone* in Europe, despite John Green's claims here. Average people, by the end of the period-soon-to-be-called-something-other-than-the-Renaissance were reading and purchasing shares in business ventures (such as voyages to the New World and Tulip bubbles).

I'm afraid that pointing out a one-digit error in my remarks on universities is not persuasive.

Name: EyeLean5280
Comments: Yes, these transitions (even the "fall" of Rome) historically took a lot longer than we are used to today. But this does not mean they didn't happen. The classical world was different from the Middle Ages and the period after the 13th century, whatever scholars ultimately choose to call it (I think they're leaning toward "early modern period" at the moment), was different from the centuries leading up to it. The Protestant Reformation, expanding literacy and...

Name: Notusedanymore
Comments: First off, I study history too, so I know that you know as much as I do that you can't just group all historians into one particular group. Furthermore, yes the internet did become mainstream and so did the nuclear age (debatable because of the minimal use of nuclear power in ratio), but you missed the point, that being that it did not affect everyone, and does not affect everyone, but it is foolish to diminish it as an age based on that fact.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments: Historians and academic history students (like myself) are not saying changes didn't take place between the mid 14th and early 17th century. It did, but so did pretty much every 3 centuries time period we have records of. It was not a "rebirth of culture, science, and rationality that swept out old, bad institutions and superstitions and ushering a better era". Therefore it would be inaccurate to call it a "Renaissance", so more and more historians use the "Early Modern" (time period debated).

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Except the nuclear age DOES effect a large number of the population. A huge number of stuff all around the world are powered by nuclear reactors. The stuff they produce effective people. People suffer the consequences of nuclear fall out and nuclear waste.
And it took less than a generation for the internet to become mainstream.
If it took 200 years until after the Renaissance, then it's more likely the Enlightenment and Industrial Revolution is what improved it, not a "Rebirth".

Name: Notusedanymore
Comments: OK, so lets say the nuclear age happened with the rise in nuclear testing in the 50's (very debatable, I know) Are you telling me that the nuclear age didn't happen simply because the discovery did not effect a large proportion of the general public, and continues not to do so? Furthermore, the internet was becoming mainstream in what, 2000? It's foolish to say it started then however. If we were going off when the actual events hit the majority, the Renaissance occurred in the Industrial Rev.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
You are using a computer are you not? Quantum Mechanics and the Internet. I can say they haven't happened to large parts of Sub-Saharan Africa, but I can't say they haven't happened.
The difference is that these "art" and new "philosophy" only impacted a lot less than 10% of the total population. Meanwhile wars, religious persecution, witch hunts, and poverty, female standing (yep) all got worse during the Renaissance when compared to the Middle Ages. This is for the other 90% of the population.

Name: Notusedanymore
Comments: So does that mean that the information age or the nuclear age hasn't happened simply because  large proportion in Africa don't have access to the internet or nuclear power?

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Except it isn't anywhere that clear cut. Pre-Renaissance scholarship already centered on Romans and the Classics. The first Universities were established in the 11th Century in Europe. Don't forget Hildegard of Bingen who John mentioned in vid14.
Life in the early and mid Renaissance for everyone not scholar/artist/clergy/aristocrat got worse.
The term Renaissance is being phased out in academic circles for being unhelpful and connotatively inaccurate, just like the Dark Ages before it.

Name: ParallelPain
Comments:
Hi John. I'm in University taking a Medieval History course. My prof also teach Renaissance History. I asked him whether he thought the actual Renaissance had any more legitimacy of being called that than the Carolingian Renaissance (Medieval Age). The answer was basically No. And labeling the period "Renaissance" is being phased out.
It was a good time for scholars and artists and people who could pay for their work (clergy & aristocrats), but a bad time for commoners.

Name: Paul Hsieh
Comments: There is no question Copernicus plagiarized ibn al-Shatir. But the question of "influence" is less clear.  What happened, is Copernicus was influenced by Martianus Capella and early translations of the Almagest. He then presented his heliocentric idea to his friends. A bishop requested he write up a more thorough explanation, after which Copernicus "crammed" by obtaining ibn al-Shatir's works. In his final treatise on the matter, he included ibn al-Shatir's models and proofs uncredited.

Name: Paul Hsieh
Comments: No, humanism *was* the philosophy of elevating the considerations of humans above religious doctrine.  This was not anti-religious, it was just pro-human.  The first humanists *were* religious.  *Secular* humanism came later.

Name: Scott Eberle
Comments: Think of an ant living on a speckled balloon. As the balloon is blown up, the speckles get farther apart and the ant realizes his balloon is expanding and therefore originally must have been very small. But there is no point on the balloon that was once "the center". In a similar way, there is no point in our universe that was once the center. All of space has been expanding, perhaps like a 4D balloon, though at this point we are not sure what the global geometry of our universe is like.

Name: WillStrop2008
Comments:
Just because it didn't "filter down" to the lowest classes right away, that doesn't make it not real. 

Think of it this way. From the very dawn of recorded history until roughly AD 600, the reliability of documents was assessed by the author's actual research methods. From the 600s to the 1st half of the 1300s, documents were considered reliable simply because they were old and their authors were good Christians. From the 2nd half of the 1300s to this very day, it's back to actual methods. (!)

Name: Geraldine SB
Comments:
If History is the attempt at identifying trends and making sense of past events, then isn't it all intellectual construct? And if it is intellectual construct, then isn't it by definition biased? 

The Renaissance is a "thing" for Europeans who study the period because it helps them make sense of the ideas and concepts that unify them today, much like the Mandate of Heaven is a thing for the Chinese because it helps them makes sense of their own present society.

The Renaissance did not only occur in Italy.  It also happened in the Netherlands and North Germany.  That's because those city-states were wealthy as well.

It's really not true that Italy was more secular.  There were more wealthy educated people in Italy (and the Hansa) and they tended to be more secular.  The general people in Europe were fairly religious.

Name: blissfulbhajan
Comments: Which is why a lot of Art throughout the ages looks so 'similar' and it is sometimes hard to tell two artists who lived at the same time apart. They sold the styles and subject matter that were popular at the time. For example, for a while the Italians liked having their portraits painted in profile rather than facing forward because they thought the profile of an  individual was more recognizable than from the front. The North was much more into the third quarter view for a long while. :]

Name: blissfulbhajan
Comments: Meaning of course, the more art of jesus and the madonna you have in your home the more you must love god, as apposed to going out an being a good person. Artists often had to add religious symbols or ideas to their pieces so they could practice and still sell it. For example Albrecht Durer, quite possibly the man who brought the Renaissance to the north, sold a ton of this hands and feet prints because he made them religious. The hands were in prayer and the feet had holes to suggest christ

Comments:
First of all, I adore this series!! <3

I would like to point out that a lot of Renaissance painters didn't paint the Madonna over and over again because they were religious (not to say they weren't) but because they were /paid/ to do so. Art was not about 'self expression' as it is known to be now but it was a profession to make money. They painted the Madonna because all the rich people and the church wanted to show how pious they were by shoving out large sums of cash for art of christ.

The Renaissance occurring in Italy was no accident, it was the result of the massive amount of trade that the Italians participated in and as a result they had so much money they spent it on the Arts. 

And the Church did have the power of execution, if you think about it excommunicating someone was similar to killing a man. People would no longer associate themselves with the excommunicatee for they would not want to risk it as well.

Name: FiniteZer0
Comments: Interestingly enough, the Italian city-states were much more secularized than the rest of Europe, which was ironic because the heart of the Catholic Church lies in the center of Italy. Why do you think the Renaissance occurred in Italy and no where else? It is because the Church's influence on Italy was not as strong as it was in Northern Europe as evidenced by the wealth of the city-states. The Church was against profit; they saw it as a sin, which is why Northern Europe was poorer than Italy.

Name: TacticusPrime
Comments:
The Papal State in what would become central Italy, would perhaps be an example of the theocratic state.  The church itself, however, was not.  It did not, in fact, collect direct taxes.  The tax system broke down across the West, and a local landholders steadily gained more power.  Some of these were bishops, but they weren't under the thumb of Rome.

Church law applied to priests but it did not have the power of execution, except when granted such by monarchs and lords.

Platonism was particularly prominent in Christian thinking in the form of the Neo-Platonism of Plotinus and others. This is actually where the theology of light behind the construction of the gothic cathedrals came from.

Comments: As for knowledge, the Catholic Church did its best at attempting to preserve the knowledge that was in the West. It is naive, nay ignorant, to say that all knowledge left the West when the Roman Empire collapsed. It is in this way the Catholic Church saved the West, at least in terms of intellectual thought.

Comments: By state, I am arguing that the Catholic Church had all the same kinds of power as a government. Name: dsydebot
Comments: Sure, he was wrong about the generation of mice. But Aristotle, and the rest of the ancients, meant something different by "elements" than what we mean. Speaking in broad terms, there are four elements to any given thing--solidity (earth), liquidity (water), gaseousness (air), and energy (fire). One may very well argue that the word "element" is better applied to the specific substances named on the periodic table, but a person doesn't become "wrong" simply because of a semantic change.

Name: treymedley
Comments: No, the logic is: the renaissance only affected a few and thus was not widespread, did not discover something new, and so wasn't really revolutionary. The renaissance is somewhat expected seeing as these discoveries were from a long line of progression going back at least as far as the 700s (so there aren't really "dark ages either"). Unlike, say, the iron age where now a peasant has a nifty new plow, the renaissance did not have the impact often attributed to it.

Name: treymedley
Comments: Unlike iron/bronze ages, which impacted everyone's lives, the Renaissance was for a few, the very rich, those they hired, and a handful in the Church. It was less revolutionary than implied now, with some of the "discoveries" going back to the 1200s, or even 700s. No one saw it as a new thing until much later & it didn't affect normal people's lives. So it's not a period in the same way the other ages are. Maybe we should just call it what it was: "Later High Middle Ages" which is much more apt.

Name: Enrico Dandolo
Comments: ... tried to find a solution without effort (alchemy), the modern Western one from the Gothic age actively changes it by experiments. Furthermore, the connection between Renaissance and Antiquity is often over-stated. Both used columns and made marble statues, but the difference is that the latter always thought in "things" while the former already thought in "functions" and "relations", as evident in the respective mathematics, law and philosophy. Cf. Oswald Spengler, The Decline of the West.

Name: Benji Smith
Comments: Well, Copernicus *theorised* that the sun was at the centre of the universe, though he didn't technically discover it.  He just created a model (later improved by Kepler), that Galileo later provided the evidence for.

Name: Enrico Dandolo
Comments: I am deeply disappointed by this episode. For one, as Oswald Spengler noted, there were no significant differences between Renaissance and Gothic ages -- the difference between a Gothic cathedral and a Renaissance palazzo is far less than that between, say, a Renaissance palazzo and a Greek temple; the pillars on the latter *hide* the tiny inside, the former accentuate it; modern science was created in the 1200s by Roger Bacon -- the ancient "scientist" observed, the early Christian/Muslim ...

Name: wratched
Comments: Copernicus did not "discover" the heliocentric model. It was a guess based primarily on aesthetics that happened to be right. It wasn't until Galileo that actual evidence for the heliocentric model was found, and not until Newton that it was universally accepted. And while it was fairly redundant by then, the first actual *proof* of the heliocentric system wasn't found until 1729 (or 1838, if you happen to be a real stickler)

Name: travelingnome87
Comments:
The printing press was also invented around this time and ideas and works were able to spread a lot faster.  Yes, most of the artwork and the literature presented at this time were scholars and artist rehashing ideas from the Greeks, but the ideas and works were new to them and they were a rediscovery to a whole new generation. 

So, yeah the Renaissance did happen and it was a thing. (also the Northern  Renaissance was totally cool and interesting and does not get enough love.)

Name: travelingnome87
Comments: Lets not say that only a few people were able to see the art. In Florence the Medicis built a courtyard that was open to all. There is art on the gates of churches, and on the walls around the city, plus courtyards full of statues open to the public. A lot of the art commissioned at this time was made for churches and it was awe inspiring whenever the altarpieces were opened to revel the work underneath. I think near the end of this time period they churches had more art then they had walls.

Name: MisterRea1
Comments: I disagree that the Renaissance "didn't happen". By the same logic, the Crusades didn't happen (took hundreds of years, didn't affect the lives of peasants who worked the land, wasn't a unified, and included a range of non-related events & trends). You could make the same statements about advances in Chinese culture, the age of exploration, or the decline of the Mongol empire. But collectively there *were* shifts in art, music, philosophy, & literature that *do* share important characteristics.

Comments: But they were completely different.  The Renaissance marks a philosophical shift from thinkers like Maimonides, Ibn Rushd, and Thomas Aquinas towards people like Pico Della Mirandola, Machiavelli and Montaigne. And it did effect a much larger population than the wealthy. The printing press made books cheap and affordable, raising the literacy rate and the devotional art in chapels made new forms of worship, the stories of the saints, and the bible accessible to those who couldn't read.

Name: Lauren Bryant-Monk
Comments: This is an incredibly simplistic view of the Renaissance. You argue that the only important thing to come out of the Renaissance is visual art and architecture, which is categorically untrue.  Neo-Platonic humanist philosophy paved the way for people like Descartes, Spinoza and Leibniz, Michel de Montaigne INVENTED the Essay, musical notation as we know it today was developed and Opera was created. The term "Renaissance" is used to describe a time period of change rather than a single event

Name: agentm83
Comments: Interesting points. One point which was left out was that the European Renaissance might not have happened if it wasn't for Jewish bankers. Usury (the lending of money for interest) was banned for European Christians during this period, so the Medici's relied heavily on Jewish bankers/money lenders to help their trade empire flourish. That's also where the ethnic stereotypes re: Jews and money come from (the fact that Jews could lend money, but Christians couldn't). History is fascinating!

Name: ExtantFrodo2
Comments: You'd expect both evolution and a designer to not toss out working templates should you not? But should you expect an intelligent designer to also copy broken templates (and to also do so in strict adherence to a nested hierarchy) - having unbroken ones in some branches while keeping the broken ones strictly within the same branch? Mindless evolution has no other option than this whereas an intelligent designer would have to deliberately restrict his ingenuity to lineage exclusive paths. There are wonderful abilities of various species that are confined to those species. Why can't you regrow a limb like salamanders do? Why do most animals make their own vitamin C but humans do not? Darwin's Theory of Evolution answers these questions. Tells you how it happened. "God did it" explains nothing. It's just an empty assertion.

Name: Simon Palmer
Comments:
Great video! But considering all the information you've gathered the map at 4:07 seems to be one really big error. That is because that is in no way the extent of the Mongol Empire in 1227. Genghis Khan did not conquer all that territory. The Mongol conquests into Europe and the Middle East happend under the leadership of Ghengis' succesor and son, gedei, and the Khagans following him. The conquest of the Song Dynasty and various lands in the far east happend under Kublai Khan. And the empire reached it's greatest extent, which is shown in this map, not in 1227 but in 1279. So that entire section is a pretty massive mistake. 

Another mistake is in 5:40, where it is claimed that the Mongol Empire split up into various Khanates after Ghengis' death. This is completely true. But you are implying, whether intentioanlly or not, that this split happend quickly. It didn't. The Empire remained united during the rules of gedei, Gyuk, and Mngke, although disputes did lead to a civil war after the latters death in 1259. Kublai Khan's reign saw the empire remain as a whole, but only nominally. The definite split of the empire came after Kublai's death in 1294, a long, long time after Ghengis' death. 

These are the two main criticisms i have about this video. The remainder of the video is great nonetheless. I'd just suggest that more thorough research be done when it comes to territorial gains, and that the split should have more information as to why and when it happend, and not imply incorrect things.

Name: Cathy Keller
Comments:
Im the education consultant for this series. Though Darwins thoughts on race did evolve over his career, in Origin of Species Darwin provided a supposedly scientific explanation for the so-called inferiority of colonized and exploited people and of women...In the Origin of Species Darwin allowed that on the scientific scale of evolution, white men were more highly evolved and accomplished than either men of other races or women of any race. (Smith, Bonnie G. Women in World History: 1450 to the Present. London, Bloomsbury
     Academic, 2020. ) It then quotes Darwin directly.  With women the powers of intuition, of rapid perception and perhaps imitation, are more strongly marked than in a man [and characteristics of the lower races, and there fore of a past and lower state of civilization.  (The quote is from Charles Darwin, The Descent of Man and Selection in Relationship to Sex. (New York: D Appleton, 1879 [1871]]), 563)

Then Bismarck backed out of the deal.

Name: Afreen
Comments:
Actually, the Analytical Engine, the SECOND invention by Charles Babbage, is the one described in this video: The difference engine could only do one task.
The Analytical Engine was a general-purpose computer (never constructed) that could do more than one task, had a sort of memory, and could be programmed. Ada Lovelace wrote programs for THAT engine, though she was also interested in the Difference Engine.

Name: CrashCourse
Comments:
In regards to a common question in the comments: "Why was Eugenics bad/bad science, a terrible idea, etc..." Here are responses from our writer and consultant. Thanks for being curious, y'all! :) 

Response 1: 

Super short version, there were a number of serious problems from the jump.

For one, eugenics assumed that people are like plants or nonhuman animals: driven primarily by instinct, capable of only so much change in a lifetimebasically, products of nature, not nurture, as we say in the episode. In fact, the opposite appears to be true about most traits. Most traits also appear to be multifactorial, meaning that, alas, there is not one gene for awesomeness, e.g., but a complex interaction among several regions of the genome, plus nurture.

Basically, the eugenicists profoundly oversimplified human genetics. They worked before the modern synthesis, so they literally got the math wrong, but moreover, they reduced human nature to a small number of classical genes, which isnt accurate.

But probably the simplest way in which eugenics was bad science was that the core publications behind the discipline were riddled by *serious* basic errors, as I believe we point out re the Kallikak study and Davenports work on race. So, even if eugenics had been right, they screwed up or falsified their own research.

***

Response 2: 

I want to be consistent with our assertion from the beginning that people in the past werent stupid, and that they were trying to make sense of the world around them.  To be fair to the eugenics enthusiasts, we really shouldnt judge their science based on our modern understanding of genetics because that would contradict the historic perspective that weve been trying to argue throughout the series.  We also shouldnt try to say it was bad science from our current moral perspective.

However, we are perfectly within our right to say it was bad science based on early 20th century standard best practices of science, which it totally was.  (Caveat that eugenics started with some scientists doing sorta legitimate investigations, but as it evolved into a social movement, there was significantly more dubious practitioners & applications of science (ie, not really science).)

First point of bad science: In a rush to make genetics responsible for everything, there was a clear blurriness between causation and correlation.  Eugenics proponents would want to look for traits (such as honest/depravity, frugalness/thrift) & look at family patterns.  There might be a very clear hereditary correlation, but that in no way means that a gene is responsible for the trait.  There was a jump to a conclusion that skipped the experimental elimination process that is key to the scientific method.  Many of the traits that the eugenicists were investigating could actually be disproven through twin studies.

Second point of bad science:  Germ theory was finally accepted & genetics seemed to be the next frontier, so lots of people jumped on the bandwagon of redefining disease.  Conditions like feeblemindedness were now categorized as diseases, which needed to be fixed or eliminated.  A hundred years later, we are still discovering what conditions are caused by pathogens, heredity, environment, etc, and we are left with a whole lot of unknowns.  Mostly, what we have learned is that it is a lot more complicated than anyone thought. 

Third point of bad science: Points 1 & 2 werent really tested in any kind of sciency way, ie with control groups, repeatable experiments, double blind parameters.  Granted, lots of those ideas really solidify over the 20th century (partly in response to the bad science of eugenics), but there was enough of an ethos of best practices that definitely shows this wasnt rigorous science.  Eugenics did a lot of data collection & observation  on their own, good aspects of science  but then used that data to look for correlation patterns.

Fourth point of bad science: Eugenicists began conflating poorly defined scientific causes, like feeblemindedness (re point 2), with social causes, like poverty or immigration or race, which created a seemingly scientific legitimacy for poorly argued ideas.  This gets more at an ethics position that even the early legitimate scientists allowed dubious science to go mainstream.

Name: Phillip Schearer
Comments: I am disappointed that the video glossed over the greatest differences between Plato and Aristotle:  How many realities are there and how do we know?  Plato = two realities, the higher one known by introspection and revelation.  Aristotle = one reality, known by our senses and our logic (which he virtually invented).  The consequences of Platonism in history have been dire, including the Dark Ages and the mass bloodshed of the 20 century.  The consequences of Aristotelianism included the Renaissance, the Enlightenment, the Industrial Revolution, and the founding of the United States.  (This summary is compressed to an extreme, but the supporting facts are all around us.)
